reviews.review_body: Exactly what I was looking for and they work great.

product_title: Vivitar VIV DKS 18 Small Camera Backpack Black
product_description: Lightweight and durably made Fit all of your camera accessories in one place Keep everything safe and organized

reviews.review_body: Great bag for the price.  Can't beat it.  It carry my laptop and my gears with a problem at SEMA.  Love it.
I bought this for my husband and we love it! Is comfortable and looks so good. A good buy., definitely recommended.
Awesome.  I can carry my Canon 5d MKIII, several lenses including the 70-200 IS and a couple of flashes.  Rugged and well built.  It's awesome
im happy! its perfect backpack for me!thank you very much!im happy! its perfect backpack for me!thank you very much!im happy! its perfect backpack for me!thank you very much!
have only used this for less than 2 months and it is already tearing apart and too late to return.
Bag is nice. One zipper broke right after removing from packaging. Not enough room to carry extra lens and flash unit.
The computer zipper broke within a day of using this. After about 5 months of use, one of the arm straps broke.
A net of inside pocket ripped with 2 days of use. Almost lost the backup battery. Seams very fragile on the inside.
amazing but not wide enough

I love the way the compartments adjust.
I bought several to  for use by field agents
Sits comfortable on your back , straps adjustable
nice secure pouch for ipad or notebook or laptop
Perfect for what I need it for. The price was right and the quality seems to be op notch! I would buy another one if I had to do it over again!
Very pleased with this backpack. Meets all my requirements. My laptop fit and had room for power supply, mouse and other pieces. Carries my Nikon body, several lenses, flash and charger.
Don't buy.  Zipper broke right away.  It is exactly what I wanted, but not great quality.  I would spend a little more and get a better product.
This bag has it All as in space. My prob is I should of got the bigger one. I have 2 big lens that have trouble fitting, and on quick shoots was hard to get out
It's not a great bag. It's just not constructed as well as I would like. Lots of open seams, and generally not as high quality as I would like from my camera bag.
Absolutely love this bag.  It holds everything.  Both Camera's and 2 lenses plus all my cards, external flash, and everything else.  WILL BUY ANOTHER!
I have a Macbook Pro 13 inch and a Nikon DLSR with 18-200 / 17-55 2.8 and a couple of prime lenses.  All fit.  Will review more when I bring all that equipment when I travel.
This backpack is just awesome... It is way more better than I thought it would be... Better than the Nikon one that they sell as if it was gold...

Absolutely perfect for my Pentax DSLR, extra lenses, flash and accessories, laptop, and-on occasion-my tripod. I love the side pouches and the adjustable velcro compartment dividers. Very comfortable straps for over the shoulder.

I've been taking this camera bag with me everywhere. Its fairly sturdy and pretty comfortable. The only complaint I have is the lack of multi storage areas and its fairly bulky.

I'd definitely buy it again though.
easy to use it
Excellent backpack at a reasonable price.  I go hiking a lot and needed and backpack for my DSLRs. Fit the bill and more, well made and comfortable on the back, glad I got it
Perfect
So far it's perfect, fits so much!!

This is the bag i was searching. I serves all my needs. weight balancing and compact design makes this bag, easy to carry with not much hazzle. I dont have to worry about stuff as it has nice supporting Padding.
Nice one indeed!!

I loved the bag, even though it was really too big for me--designed of men, I think--but then the zipper failed on one side of the back pouch (the one for the computer) after only a few weeks of use. I was able to return it for credit.

Great backpack, I can fit two cameras, 3 prime lenses and one telephoto. Three speed lights and four triggers and a 15" laptop! Very heavy of course but it's nice for traveling. Will buy a dolly to put it on.
Holds my Nikon D7100 with three extra lenses and all accessories nicely.

This bag works perfectly for me. I own a Nikon D3200 and it fits into this bag with ease. The computer compartment fits my 15in Mac book perfectly (and seems to provide adequate padding). The rest of the compartments are great for storing additional accessories. Great bag all around.
Nice Pack, zippers could be better but all in all worth the investment.

I got tired of carrying around my second camera body at events and this bag really helped take away the stress from 1 shoulder and evened me out. I can fit 1 camera body and a few lenses without a problem and also use it to hold my tripod.

Great quality backpack and nice that it is customizable on inside for trips. I can take some clothes or other devices on it too like my laptop. Taken it csmping twice and anytime I go out of town and its held up great.

Just what I needed. Its not expensive but feels like it could be. Plenty of storage. Plenty of openings. The tripod foot pocket could be a little bigger but works for my tripod. I actually managed to fit pretty much everything in this bag.
I am quite happy with the bag- as a camera bag, which is why I got it. As a laptop bag- I have no opinion as all my laptops are 15" or larger.
the backpack is bigger than I thought, but is ok for the people who have a lot of things to keep. bye

I bought this based on the more generous technical specs of 18" x 10.5" space for a laptop. Well, that is wrong, the product description of 16" x 9.5" is correct so I wasted my time buying this and have to return it. Too bad Amazon can't get their listings right! Still need to find one for my trip to Maine!
I'm very happy with the this bag.  Lots of room (for what I do). Laptop fits nicely, easy to get in and out.
Zippers failed on it after just few uses, yet too late to claim a warranty defect

It's good quality & low price bag. It's easily to hold everything I need - Canon 60D, 24-105L & 70-300L lens, Canon HF200, & all accessories (filters, extra batteries, clean staffs..). I did use to carry computer (12.3") once. It's working fine. I even forgot I had laptop w/ me! It's also very comfortable & well designed.

I bought this bag about 8 months ago.  It was great for the first month, but after that you realize how cheap this bag is.  The mesh pocket on the top compartment ripped when I reached my hand in it to grab a filter.  It doesn't hold the camera and lenses securely.  The dividers are very flimsy which also doesn't help that the velcro holding them in place is not very strong.  Zippers feels cheap.  I should of just paid more for the Tamrac Evolution bag that this one copies.
This bag is really good for professional photographer. I have to return this Item because this is too big for my need.
Is perfect when you hace just a few things , but is too small for people with a lot of lenses, flashes, etc...
Overall this is a great product, my only complaint is the tripod strap. It would work better on one side or the other of the pack rather than in the middle.
Exactly what I expected. Lots of room for my cameras and equipment.
I can fit everything I need in this bag. The shoulder straps are padded well and the compartments work great with all my items! It was shipped quickly and was priced well.

It’s very compact bag and looks small from outside
But it can take all your stuff with no issue
Very well pated
Separators are good but not as strong as they should be

After about a year of use the shoulder straps started to rip away from the bag and then the metal bracket on the bottom of the shoulder strap broke.  I would pack a lot of gear into the bag, so it was pretty heavy when I used it, but I would expect to be able to fill up the bag and have it hold up.  It was a nice design, but obviously not going to hold up carrying around a lot of gear.

Good quality for the price you pay. Some cheap bag often uses super cheap material that makes the bag smell, but this doesn't. The zips work well, and the compartments of the bag are great and handy too. Will recommend budget/entry photographers with a bit of gear.?

This thing is great. It holds the majority of my equipment and makes it super simple to carry. Might be one of my favorite purchases for equipment in a long time. The only thing I wish is that the sleeve in the back portion was closed at the bottom so I could use it as a place to store my iPad when the computer compartment is being occupied.
Wonderful Bag holds all my  photo gear plus a place to put my lap top to edit & send photo on the go all in one go bag ! Well made bag.

I bought this camera bag in hopes that it would last long, well i was wrong. Iv had this bag a little over a month now and its started to fall apart already, the shoulder straps are coming apart around the seems and the separators in the bag are coming apart as well. I definitely won't be buying a bag like this again. It does seem well built when you first buy it, but just wait a little bit it'll come apart. The gear that I'm carrying is a 1d mark iii, 24-70 2.8 a sigma 18-50 and 50 mm 1.8 and my mac book.....i guess thats too heavy for the bag because the shoulder straps have already began to tear. if your looking for a camera bag PLEASE save up your money and just buy a APE CASE camera book bag......its worth it

My husband loves this! He has  all his photography accessories in it and ready for his camera to be loaded at any moment, he has  had this for over a year now and although it's well used, it's  in about the same shape add when it arrived! This is a wonderful gift that seems like it'll last a lifetime!

Great bag for all of my photo shoot essentials. The only issue is that it's now too heavy to carry on my bag, which is why I ordered a trolley insert. Putting it on wheels makes it the best bag that I've had so far. You get a lot of bang for your buck. It's very sturdy so it protects your valuable equipment and it didn't cost an arm and a leg.

The order was delivered promptly. It was very well packaged and had the new car smell, but just as a car would do, It immediately began to depreciate once it left the lot. The Vivitar DKS-18 Photo/SLR/Laptop Sling Backpack (Black) is Horrible. The shoulder straps are coming apart, the zippers are breaking, threads are loose all over the entire bag, the side Velcro pocket is coming off and I don't even use it! This bag is cheap because it is made cheap. It is a mask waiting to come off. I have had this backpack for less than 3 months and have not gotten my money's worth at all. Spend the money for a quality backpack. You'll thank me later.

I absolutely the layout and access to the contents within this backpack, but after six weeks as my daily driver carrying a 15" MacBook Pro, 5D2 with 24-70 2.8, 50mm 1.4, two speedlights, and cables, the bag is literally falling apart at the seams.  Very poor stitching inside and out (see photos) means I simply can't trust my livelihood to a bag that may rip open at any moment.  Two weeks past the Amazon return period, it's likely 50 dollars I won't be getting back.

If you plan only only using this backpack for weekend trips or a few vacations a year, it might hold out for you - but as a daily carry, look elsewhere.

I've only taken  it out once so far, but it is very comfortable in the backpack mode (I don't think I'll ever use it in the sling mode, as it seemed a little awkward when I tried it), and has lots of room for my Nikon D5100, two lenses, tripod, plus lots of room for extras, filters, and other small equipment.  Another reviewer mentioned that the pack sits too low on the back, even when straps are pulled tight, but I got around this by removing the pads at the bottoms of the straps, which weren't doing anything anyway, and then was able to cinch the straps tighter and get it where I wanted on my back.  I am planning on travelling with this pack and I think it will do the job for me.  Even if it only lasts one year, for the price you can't go wrong.

Loved it. its perfect for me. My camera is a micro 4/3 Olympus OMD and everything fits perfectly.  I can definitely see this being a bit too small for those with a big DSLR and lens combo.

Was even able to pack my laptop on the back side too!
The protective rain guard that came with is was also amazing. I was really happy since it rained while i was out with it.

no cons.

I was hoping the price was not too good to be true. I took this bag on a one week trip. The chest strap ripped off on the first day. The thread is very thin and cheap, the sewing was not done very well. The inner compartment padding ripped on day two. The velcro also tore off from just the weight of my lens against it. The compartments were flimsy and didn't hold my gear in place. The zippers weren't very good, but smoothed up a bit after some use. It was comfortable, and I really wanted to like it, but it was just too cheaply made. Going to get a Kata 3n1 bag like i should have to begin with.

The product is just what you expect, if you have the need to carry a DSLR with multiple lenses and attachments along with your laptop/Ipad then this is the right bag.
The construction of the bag is solid and it is currently holding all the items above along with a tripod.

The seller DataVision Computer Video - are just great.  I ordered it yesterday at 11AM and had it today at 9AM, since thats the earliest FEDEX would deliver.

I have used this bag a lot and it's pretty good. Lots of space for lenses and the camera. The downside are the straps are complete garbage. They don't hold tight. The zippers are also cheap. The main zipper unzipped and  a $300 lens fell to its demise. If they would only fix the straps and zippers, this bag would be amazing.

This is a nice backpack.
Very big, with lots of space.
I've had no problems with the zippers so far.
Could have more internal pockets.
Nice padding but some sewing of the internal divisors are off, no big deal, but could be better.
Great buy for the price!

good backpack,  some of the straps broke sooner than i would of expected like the chest and waist straps, but everything else still works fine. has alot of extra storage room, could be  a little more comfortable.

I've been buying this backpack every year, yeah the zipper doesn't last that long, it's made of cheap material, also shoulder strap is too thin. but the back pack it self is good, if I can afford it I'll replace all the zipper with YKK zippers and exchange the straps, but it's cheaper to buy a new one when the zipper breaks.

Purchased  bag for extended travel.  Overall dimensions and function were what I was looking for,  but the shoulder strap seams separated and made bag unstable.  Returned for refund. The tripod straps would be better placed on side  than on rear of bag.  I liked the bag and wished it held up better,  but my camera equipment is too  expensive to take a chance.

Bought this for my wife about a week ago and she LOVES it.

Works flawlessly, the multiple pocket accessibility is fantastic along with the generous amount of storage.

Carries her Nikon D600 with 3 lenses, including 1 300mm

I would say I'd buy it again but I don't ever seeing it breaking on me

Perfect to carry on a plane and lasted her pretty well in some heavy rain

This bag is phenomenal it fits my nikon d5100 with 18-55mm and 55-300 lenses perfectly along with other various accessories and my 12 inch tm2 laptop and its accessories. I took this bag on my honeymoon to St. Lucia and got fantastic pics with my camera but while i was out the weather decided it would be a perfect time to storm everywhere so i immediately pulled out the rain cover that this bag comes with and not a single thing got wet!

Looking for a backpack to fit my Canon 7D and 15in laptop. For the price, it's great. My laptop is not a skinny little MacBook and it fits fine! I don't expect this backpacks durability to last forever,but for $45 (compared to others exactly the same around $80) it'll work for a few years! Super satisfied!

I have loved this bag! I needed a bag that would hold both my camera gear and lap top. This bag gets the job done. It has lots of padding for my camera and lens to keep them safe. It also has a few different access points to get to the equipment. It is not bulky, it is the perfect size. I don't even feel like I'm carrying a camera bag when I'm carrying it. I love that you can change the straps from a backpack to a sling. It is overall a great bag.

Seems relatively well made. Snug for the laptop compartment, but ample room for camera gear. I'm not sure I'll be able to use this as my only carry-on, but I am going to try.

On the downside, how is this a sling? It's almost impossible to carry this bag over one shoulder, and that's what sling says to me.

Like any avid photographers I am always looking for the perfect camera bag. It does not exist of course because there are too many human to consider: How much weight do you want to carry, how much equipment do you own and so on. So I have many camera bags and change them too often. But down to specifics: This bag is excellent value for money, seems quite well made and is light weight enough to make it useful. I would like a bit more versatility in the removable partitions but let's be serious, this is not a $250.00 bag.
I recommend it!

Wished Camera storage section had more flexibility. For me, upper storage would be more practical if it was "box like" design, rather than "full open". Side storage not very accessable and usefull. Outside access would have been better. Finaly, the Tripod storage devise (I assume, there was no manual), was not practical for a standard tripod - no lower support.
Backpack overall size was ok, and material seemed strong. Just purchased, so time will tell.
I guess overall, I should be satisfied for the price. I am not a professional Photographer (yet).

Well made with lots of room.  Material feels good and straps seem strong.  I like that the straps have metal claps for easy removal.  Padding inside could be a little better, and small laptop just barely fits, but no real worry about the gear inside.  Very happy with the item, especially at this price.

Took this pack on a two week trip to Europe.  I had it with me for my everyday travel.  It carried my camera with two lences, a light sweater, a snack, my wallet and easily fit my tablet in the sleave.

The straps were a little long I had to retighten them once a day.

This is an awesome camera bag for my needs !!! I just wish there was more pockets like the one on top where you can put more than just flat stuff like SD cards and cleaning clothes but so far I love it ! My laptop fits perfectly and I still have space for my charger !
No more hassle at the airport with 3 different bags !

Best bag i've had for my camera. I put all my lenses, back up battery, charger, light, mic, tripod mount, memory, and laptop in this bag every time I travel. It can get pretty heavy but everything holds solid and stays well protected. I don't recommend testing yourself, but I went through a fall on a concrete floor with the bag on and my camera and laptop survived. My laptop had slight ding to the corner but nothing in comparison to what I had imagined. Camera and all lenses were completely safe. In summary, perhaps they could add a little more cushion to the laptop side, but other than that it is a great bag.

On the second use the stitching on one of the shoulder straps started to break. The netting on the inside pockets started pulling apart the first time I put something in it. We will see how the warranty depart handles this.
On the upside, the bag fits my needs perfectly. Holds my 17" laptop with a little extra room to spare. Holds all of my camera equipment and has room let for a second camera. The hidden flap for the tripod legs was a wonderful surprise. The bag is very comfortable and the chest and hip straps make long picture hikes easy.

Actions taken by the warranty will decide my overall satisfaction to either 1 or 5 stars.

I've had this back for 4 years and its been great, makes you look like you know what your doing when you pull out your camera, people love my setup and started taking me more serious as a photographer and film maker, but on the 4th year, the zippers start to want fall off, and its not as big in side as I need it to be, so upgrading. this great beginner bag, and laptop holder is great. For mac books. If you take out the inside you can fit 3 lenses plus a lens on your camera and a handle for filming.

I loved this bag while I had it, it held everything for me.

I went on a motorcycle trip through Europe and this was a trooper, it was easy to attach to the back of the bike, and the one time I forgot to attach it and it fell off and was dragged for almost 10 miles, everything was protected although the bag itself was beat to hell. A little duct tape and the bag lasted me through the rest of that trip like a champion.

I bought a different bag as a replacement, but i am thinking about scraping that one to re-buy this one instead just because I like the bag so much better.

I was carrying a 40D, 20D, 4 lenses, GoPro, Lumix PnS, and a Toshiba video camera in this bag on the trip.

I purchased this bag because I have a lot of lenses and flash units among a light meter and assorted filters and needed a bag that would hold just about everything I own and this bag hit the mark and passed with flying colors.  This bag comes with at tripod holder and comes with a rain cover.  It is sturdy and is well made.

My bag actually has in it right now a Nikon D3200 Camera, a Tamaron 70-300mm lens, Nikon 55-200mm lens, Nikon 18-55mm lens, Nikon 50mm lens, and Nikon SB-700 Flash, a small no name flash, a Macro LED Ring Flash, Interfit Flash Meter, Lens Filters, Flash Filters, Nikon MC-DC 2 Remote Release Cord, Camera off shoe TTL Flash Cable, Latop, Lens cleaning kit, owner manuals along with tripod and other accessories.  I really love this bag!!

The backpack is well-made, has lots of nice features such as plentiful zippered web pockets, etc, includes a rain cover, and is easily adjustable for fit. The interior configuration is difficult to change much, so unless you are using a 35mm SLR or a standard DSLR, it isn;t as flexible as I would have preferred. I use a medium format camera setup and it is not able to securely change configuration for my equipment. The price is right, however. In addition, I am a very big, beefy guy and this adjusts quite well to fit me. That's definitely worth a star on its own.

They have thought of everything ... holds my laptop with adequate padding, my dslr, lenses, accessories and even the tripod ... comes with a rain cover that i have already used and kept everything dry ... love the versitility of backpack straps or sling back conversion or waste straps or chest strap plus it has a handle on the top, a handle on the side and a pocket to slide the bag on a trolley type piece of luggage  ...  was tired of using 2 bags while traveling with my laptop and my camera  ... this solved everything with adequate room and room for more camera accessories plus with all the velcro I can reconfigure the insides if necessary  ... it is not too bulky or too heavy and can be used while traveling, biking, walking, hiking, etc.  .... in love with the versitility

My old KATA bag got stolen, and I got this bag. It has the same basic idea of the design, and is built relatively well. For it's price it's definitely better than the "new and improved" KATA 3-in-1 line, which turned out to be a huge disappointment. The only reason I could not use this bag and returned it is because I use a battery grip on my Canon 6D. The side opening is just a bit too small to get the camera out easily. However, if you use no battery grip, or use a smaller body (Rebel series or 60D) - it would be great. It will fit a camera with the attached 70-200, couple of extra lenses, a flash or a second body, and still has a sizable top compartment for small items, bottle of water, or even a light jacket or sweater. Fantastic value for the price!

I purchased this item and found it to be a bit bulky. Because of that, the sling option was very uncomfortable, it was okay as a backpack, but not as a sling. The bag might also prove to be a problem if you're apt to shove it under the airline seat in front of you. So, I decided to return it ASAP.

I was told by the company - Stereo Advantage - that I would would have to cover the return shipping costs because it was no fault of theirs that I was unhappy. Well, ummm, okay. I agreed, although this is the first time I had to cover that expense since shopping on-line. That cost was $7.32  Then I got my refund notice, they also hit my credit card for the "free" shipping I received when it was sent out. This must have been in the fine print somewhere. That amount, for some reason (keep in mind that I accepted the free ground shipping option), was almost twice as much: $13.24

The grand total for returning this item was $20.56 - If I had known this, I would have kept it, to either give away or sell at a cheap price and give someone a deal.

In this day an age, where the competition is steep for my on-line dollar, Stereo Advantage will not be receiving one more cent from me. Be cautious when purchasing this item from Stereo Advantage, for returning it, if you are not happy with it, will make you even more unhappy.

Please note, camera backpacks are one of the most frequently returned items. My source for that was a camera department sales rep at B&H.

Stereo Advantage - Return Scam Artists

I bought this back pack to hold my laptop and camera gear and was very pleased with the quality overall. As several people have noted some of the zippers already have problems ( the one inside the case  already unzips itself). As long as the outside zippers work, I can deal with that. Bag is larger and heavier than I expected, but so is what I put into it. I ended up wishing that the bag was a little larger so I could put more equipment in it. The chargers fro everything take up a lot of room so they will have to live in the area I was going to use for something else. I underestimated what I was planning on putting in this bag.

Gonna have to say some not-so-great things about this one.

Cons:

-Pretty cheap interior material. I feel like I'm fighting to not rip it when I organize the dividers. The zippers feel cheap as wel as well. I'm worried they might break in the near future.
-Never seen this in a backpack, but the straps don't go as high as I want...I pull it up to the maximum height on my back, and it's not high enough for me (I'm 6' 2").
-There's an obnoxious 24 inches (at least) of extra strap hanging when I pull it up to the maximum height (fixable). Again, not something I've ever had a problem with in a backpack...
-There's absolutely no soft area to put more fragile things like filters.
-The laptop area has ZERO padding.

Pros:
-Chest and waist strap
-Comes with a rain protector
-Place to put a tripod
-Can be used as a sling (haven't done it but I suppose it could be useful)

Overall, it's an average camera backpack. My biggest qualm is the cheap interior/no padding. I'm going to try to make it work, but maybe go with something else.

I'm pleased with my purchase.
Seemed to be cheaper on Amazon than most other places. +free shipping ;-)

Pros: It is sturdy, made with good strong material. Fairly Spacious, with a fair amount of room for accessories.  The compartments are adjustable to fit around your gear and decently padded.
Comes with a rain cover to keep the pack dry in inclimate weather. The adjustable straps are padded and comfortable to use.
Will fit about a 14" laptop in the zippered compartment.

Cons: the small fold out pocket that is used to support carrying a tripod (at the front base of the backpack) is a tad small if you have a tripod with beefier legs. You may have to get creative to utilize this piece. Slightly smaller than anticipated but then again, I have a bunch of accessories.

Final thoughts:  I like this backpack and would recommend it.
If I were to buy one again, I would probably choose ("personally" the dks 25) as it does have a little more room and space to stow gear.
 4 stars.

This bag has held up after 3 years of good hard use. I go out on nature walks and camping trips multiple times a week and since September of 2015, this things hauled everything I had. I only write this review now because I've outgrown it. It held my D500 with 70-200 and 11-16mm perfectly, along with all the batteries, cards, cables and everything I'd need for a days trip out, as far as camera gear is concerned. It never let me down, though one of the zipper handles did snap this year. I never felt it lacked anywhere for what I needed. It did not have the poor construction quality that some reviews are showing. Everything was pretty solid. My only wish was for better zippers. That's a big deal to some people. I just picked up the LowePro 450 AW II and the zipper quality difference is huge. But otherwise it's a great bag at a great value.

read lots of complaints about this.  I have not traveled with it yet, but I will soon.  The zippers seem to be just as strong as the my name brand camera backpack that I spent 3x the amount on.  the inside space seems fine.  I have my canon 60d in there with a Tamron lens 35-270. I also packed a 52 mm and a 75-300 zoom.  that still leaves me with room for my go pro and a few accessories. (this is just inside the padded camera compartment)  the top seems to have plenty of room for extra batteries and chargers.  I looks like I can even pack my laptop cables up top.  There a few other net zipper compartments for the smaller accessories.  My laptop fits fine, it sits low in its area so I room on top to throw in the mouse and probably the power cord if it doesn't fit it the other compartment.  The one thing that the description did not mention is that the side quick access for the camera is reversible.  meaning that there is one on each side of the pack.  you just have to reconfigure the insides so it works for you.  it doenst matter if your a lefty (poor suckers) or a righty, you can make it work either way.  Cant beat it for the money and I have spent lots on camera bags in the past.

I think I gave this pack a test most people would cringe thinking about, so here's my story. I am a professional photographer. I recently took a train trip from Grand Rapids, Michigan to Portland, Oregon on Amtrack. 2500 miles on a train with a 3 hour layover in Chicago Union Station. I carried this pack, never putting it down for 6 solid days with a 15" laptop, two large DSLR's, battery chargers,smart phone and "travling junk". The compartments are interchangeable inside the main camera compartment and easily changed around for the needs of the kind of lenses you want to carry etc. The velcro could be just a tick more friendly but it got the job done. I easily carried two DSLR's with lenses and an extra telephoto lens. I read a review the laptop compartment was "tight" so two days before the trip I stuffed the laptop compartment with photo albums to stretch it out and it worked like a charm. If I had it to do over again, I would have stretched it for a week. The laptop made it safe and sound and so did the cameras. The pack is a little heavier than I thought it would be but you need more than a feather to protect this kind of equipment. It came quickly and I'm very happy with it. You cant beat this for the price.

I want to start off by saying this bag is HUGE! Biggest backpack like thing Ive ever own. The picture doesnt do it justice.

I like this bag. It has space for everything you might need, and I'm big on bringing extra stuff just in case, with this bag, I can fit them all. I had my Canon t3i, My Canon hand camera (dont remember the name), Panasonic lumix LX5, Tablet, Rode mic, flood light, batteries, Tascam DR40, extra cords and batterys, plus I was able to tie a shoulder rig on the outside.. Its basically like carrying a mobile suitcase. This bag was comfortable, and straps helps to keep it on.

I fell in love with this bag, but 20 mins into using it, some of the mesh on one of the pouches already started to give out (PS: I started to give this bag 4 stars,but I figure it should last at least 1 day before falling apart). The price of this bag was DEFINITELY withing reach compared to the rest. I think this is a great bag for people who tend to carry a lot of items.

Pros: Big, space for everything, comfortable, Big, secure, lots of compartments for your stuff, and big. Has space for Camera, tons of equipment, cords, and specialized laptop/tablet space. THE PRICE MAKES THIS A WINNER!

Con: Its big (which can be a problem for some), mesh was coming apart day 1 for me, so I suspect after a year I might need to find a new one. No quick easy access. So if youre looking to quickly grab your camera, you couldnt set it up that way but it doesnt easily lend itself to that.

I've had this backpack for 3 days. It is a very well designed backpack with plenty of compartment space to store all of your necessary items for photography. I bought this backpack specifically for my one-day trip to Sequoia National Park. Although I was driving the majority of the time, I would take my backpack with me along the small trails to see the sites. Halfway through my trip I noticed that the shoulder strap on the right side has already started to tear away from the body of the bag.

Originally I packed the following items in the bag to begin my trip:

Mac Book Pro 13.3 inch laptop (not carried to Sequoia)
Phone, wallet, keys, and camera cleaning kit
300mm Sigma lens
Pentax k-30 camera with 55mm lens (mostly in hand, not in bag)
2 very small point and shoot cameras
Tripod strapped to the back

With everything inside and strapped on to the bag, I would say the the bag weights a good 20-25 lbs, however it was constructed to hold that amount of stuff.

Although I think that this bag is a wonderful item for any photographer on the go, I am quite disappointed that the strap was not very well constructed. Now I must Frankenstein my shoulder strap so that I can continue using and abusing it. I might as well do it to both straps to ensure security from any future tears.

When looking through the reviews for this product, I was worried that it would not be able to hold my Tamron 70-300mm, as other bags I was looking at could hold it at a tight squeeze. Now that I have the bag, it is the least of my worries - the bag can hold the lens standing upright (when bag is flat on its back)! Putting on the lens with the hood attached on my D5100, there is no trouble putting it in the body compartment either, in fact it still has a good amount of space after the lens for another compartment.

The bag (main compartment) can hold my D5100, Tamron 70-300mm, Tokina 100mm f/2.8 and a kit lens 18-55 with only half the space filled up. It would be able to hold another 3 lenses well! I appreciate the small zips here and there to put really small things like cleaning cloth, remote control and extra lcd protectors.

Pros: Good space for photographers with lots of equipment. I've put in my 13'' laptop in it and it fits well too. The compartments can be adjusted easily and thus my equipment feels quite secure. The top space is really big, enough to put in small notebooks, binoculars and other bulky items.

Cons: Too much space for photographers like me with just 3 lenses - I end up putting my lens hoods in the other empty compartments. This results in the bag being too unnecessarily bulky, and the compartments aren't sealed, so small items do travel around the bag when carried. The straps are comfortable and thick, but that causes some restrictions when sliding it around to retrieve equipment.

When I first got this backpack, I loved it.

It's the perfect size and, for the price, you get a good deal of space and features. Sadly, the quality is sub-par. After less than six months of use (received this as a gift from my wife for Xmas), the stitching on shoulder straps (particularly the right one) has been ripped from top of the bag and are hanging on for dear life by but a few threads - rendering it useless with my more than $3k worth of gear.

I will admit, I shoot and use my equipment quite regularly, removing the backpack frequently to grab gear as necessary. And, I pack my bags full, using every compartment - which one would think the backpack was designed to withstand.

Again, for moderate users who don't plan on filling the bag with gear (and thus weighing it down) - it may be sufficient but why bother? If you're not going to fill the bag with gear, then bring along a smaller, lighter backpack.

Again, while the bag was fantastic when first purchased, it has failed miserably from a quality of construction standpoint. Take my advice, pass on this one.

The technical details of this specify it will fit a 17" Laptop. Definitely not true, as that would be the DKS-25 ( [...] ) . However the bag itself is great. Luckily, used it to fit my smaller work laptop, which fits perfectly (14.6").

The compartments themselves are well padded, and the accessibility to the sides as well as front zippers is awesome! Being able to change from a shoulder-slung to a cross-slung to a backpack is also great :) The top compartment holds a surprising amount of stuff as well.

Total stuff in the bag currently:
Canon T3i + 18-55 kit lens + Hood
Canon 55-250mm Lens + Hood
Canon 50mm 1.8 Lens + Hood
Macro Extenders
Ring Light + battery pack + DC adapter (cheap macro stuff)
Polarizing filter/UV filter
2 Portable HDDs
AA Battery Charger
Phone Charger Cables + Wall adapters
Laptop Charger cables
14.6" IBM Laptop

So, it does fit a significant amount of stuff. Couldn't be happier with the purchase!

The Good: This item is cheap. Backpack has a lot of storage. *THIS BACKPACK IS VERY COMFORTABLE to wear*. All straps are easy to pull(for loosening and tightening. Backpack is a very comfortable size.

The Bad: This is important to read: there are NOT enough dividers in this backpack to perfectly layout your setup. I was so very disappointed in this, because ease of organizing your gear is CRUCIAL! This backpack has so much storage space, but with the difficulty of organizing, you can't use all of it! Also, the velcro that lines the walls to customize your layout is not all over the interior perimeter, which makes it very difficult to place a wall exactly where you cant it. I combined all of the dividers from my previous Amazon pack with this one, and still did not have enough to make my layout perfect. Also, the interior does seem a little thin on the padding. I'm not so sure this backpack can effectively keep your gear cushioned, but we should never be throwing our backpacks to the ground anyways I guess.

The Verdict: This is a great product. Please don't let the huge wall of text in,"The Bad" get me wrong. There is a lot to love here. If you are planning on upgrading from an Amazon Basics bag for more comfort and capacity, THIS IS A GREAT LOW COST CHOICE! With the divider trouble though, you're going to have to do some work (and using old dividers) to get your setup right. I really hope Vivitar is kicking themselves in the pants for skimping on the dividers.

I'm hoping this review will dissuade anyone considering purchasing this bag. I purchased this bag Brand New for a vacation I had to New York, and immediately began regretting it. I have provided pictures of all the issues. Firstly, this bag does NOT fit a 17" laptop, my 17" portable display barely fits in this bag and that has no bezels whatsoever. So unless your 17" laptop has no bezels and hinges right at the bottom of the display, this bag will not fit your laptop. Second, the bottom of the shoulder straps are mounted on a swiveling clip, so as you slide this bag on and off to access your camera, the straps will rotate on this clip and eventually cause the very thin and soft nylon strap to pinch on the adjustment clip. This doesn't sound like a big issue, but once the strap gets pinched, the adjustment clip just slips and you will need to readjust the your straps every 15 minutes. Getting the strap unpinched and back straight is a huge pain and something that should have NEVER been an issue if they hadn't decided to reinvent this part of a backpack. This slip caused me to injure one of my shoulders after 2 weeks in NY, I should have tossed this bag earlier. Third, the upper compartment zipper material is very thin, so after 20-30 uses, the metal zipper began catching on the fabric portion of the zipper and the zipper would not close. I have never had this happen in my 30+ years of life. Fourth, the belt clip on this backpack is hidden inside the luggage handle slot on the rear of the bag, but is not held in place with anything. Expect this belt strap to just randomly drop repeatedly, you'll just need to tuck it back in place, without any means of keeping it there. Fourth, I was using this bag with a Canon R5, 20-70mm f/2 L & a Sigma 14mm f/1.8 and the dividers are only held in place with small straps of velcro so my lenses were clashing into each other continuously. Seriously, don't waste your money, time or body on this bag.

I'm an amateur photographer and I purchased this to take with me on nature photography hikes.  I keep all of my gear (lenses, various cables, cloths) in this pack and it doesn't feel heavy after several miles.  I currently carry my kit and "nifty fifty" lenses and feel I could easily include a longer lense in this pack once I'm able to upgrade.  I also purchased the Amazon full sized tripod (not travel sized) and it fits well in the tripod strap on the back.  I have to make sure to tighten it really well otherwise there is some bounce and noise, but otherwise it's minimal.  The side pockets a nice feature, especially when the tripod is still on the pack as it blocks the front compartment access panel.  The top access panel is large enough left to right to include a 32oz Rubbermaid leakproof water bottle for your treks and is seperate from the rest of the pack so you don't have to worry about rummaging around for personal items. This backpack has plenty of little mesh pockets inside the flaps with zipper covers as an added touch to keep them from scratching your gear.  I haven't tested the sling pack aspect yet, but like that it has that flexiblity.  This pack doesn't fit my 16" widescreen laptop, but easily would fit my corporate work laptop.  My netbook fits with plenty of room for the power charger to be included within the sleeve if I wanted.  Overall, I love this pack.

When I received the bag I was actually surprised at its size.. It is a fairly medium to large sized pack(almost school book bag sized..not as wide)..I'm 5'11" and it's not huge, but not too small and female looking(on a man).
The reviews discussing the interior materials and Velcro quality are VERY true as far as plan your positioning and use your fingers to separate the velcro( so to relieve the pressure of tearing)... Mine did tear a bit and the nylon is tough to repair.. But it is what it is... I sewed it up as best I could, put it where it's gonna stay, you aren't gonna see it! and on with life! Exterior quality seems to be fine.. I know other reviews mention zipper issues.. I have not had any as of yet! Used a few times in and out-doors(cold weather). Will keep you posted as to in the future.
As for capacity... It will hold some gear! If you have 8 lenses and diffuser screens and multiple slave flashes a camcorder, 6 p.&s cameras, etc.. NOT what your lookin for!! I have my T3i w/ 18-55mm attached, 75-300mm( can also fit mounted), filters, batteries, chargers, various cords, hoods...and have room for a point & shoot and my handycam in the bottom...top enough space for a lunch or rain poncho and some trinkets( your not going out for a 3 day camp with just this!!). For a day at the park, or at a venue ..Perfect..maybe a tad bulky but..all-in-all..
CONCLUSION: For $50...it gives you the size, ability, and style of the KATA, Tamrac,etc at a 1/3 of the cost.. If your a professional(getting paid for your shots, and traveling 340 days for it)..you don't need or wouldn't be looking at this bag!!.. If your going a vacations, and taking the family to the theme park or day hikes/bikes then, this is a GOOD BUY!!! Yes you may have to fix an issue or two, you will probably customize it, and you will be able to determine if it is comfortable as a sling or not..for me.. Long hours of wear(backpack mode), an hour or two(sling is fine) yes, the padding is a bit funky for sling but I found that I can adjust it so it doesn't rub my neck..look as I said.. It's a backpack with options..which is why we are all looking at it!! And like me this is the 100th review you have read and have narrowed down your 2 or 3 choices and makers... I chose this one and I am satisfied completely with cost and above cost quality..should last for a while and do what I need it to! Hope this helps all those like me who obsess over research, products and manufacturers, etc...before buying.. But then again "to each his own.."

Update: It has now been over 6 years since I bought this backpack! I'm finally ready to buy a new bag, but this thing held up wonderfully. I'd have never expected a $50 camera bag to last this long with nearly daily use. Let me tell you what broke, and why I'm looking at other options, but before I do I should clarify that this is still a five-star product due to how long it lasted.

Failure points:
The fabric dividers have started coming apart. The stitching holding them together simply couldn't take any more abuse. I've dealt with this for a few months, but the final straw was the zipper breaking on one of the side access flaps.

Design flaws:
1. The straps have WAY too much length to them, and not enough options to retain excess material, meaning my bag has always been covered in hanging strap excess. You could tape things up, but that would only be putting a band-aid on the problem.
2. The divider pads are too soft, and they give way very easily. Often my equipment would end up jumbled, at least after the first few years of use.
3. The shape of the top zipper enclosure is just silly. The way that it flairs out makes it floppy and annoying to deal with one-handed.
4. The top compartment has inadequate pockets for keeping items organized. It just wound up as a jumbled mess in the end.
5. Some of the outside (side) pockets are uselessly small
6. The tripod holding system is junk. I wouldn't keep a $10 monopod on there.

With all that said, it has survived to this day. If I can't find something else with the convinient quick-access side and similar size, I'll probably just buy another one of these.

Original Review:
I've had the Vivitar for over three years now.  I am a professional photographer (or at least, people pay me to take pictures and it is my only revenue stream) and this bag goes to every shoot.  I've only now started to see some wear and breakdown, which is a damn long service life for such an inexpensive bag.

About the bag:
I can carry a 5D MK3 (with or without grip) along with my flash, a 70-200 L and two normal sized lenses (a 20mm and a 17-40).  I also carry 6 batteries, extra memory cards, a laser tape measure and lots of odds and ends.  I can even stick a good sized tablet or small laptop in the provided pouch.

The big selling point for me with this bag is how you can sling it sideways on your front and pull your camera right out, ready to shoot.  The top access works great when you use it like a normal bag and set it on a table to switch lenses.

Pros:
+Strong handles and straps.  They're all still in place and working
+Comes with a rain cover that doesn't cover the straps, so you can keep on trekking
+Plenty of little pockets and spaces for various things, including zipper closed netting pouches in the top segment
+Tough enough for regular use.  I wouldn't take it on lots and lots of outdoor shoots, but if you shoot indoors, it stands the test of time
+Small and compact enough to not look like a paratrooper when you're walking around
+Good strong zippers, no problems there! All the zipper pulls are still intact too
+Comfortable

Cons:
-The dividers are flimsy, as with all other camera bags I've used.  They still work though
-The monopod/tripod holder is only good for small, light units.  It won't carry anything I own.  The strap for it also has little resistance, allowing it to come lose.
-Because there are three sides you can open, sometimes I would forget and leave one open, though somehow none of my gear has fallen out yet.  I know this just sounds like me being an idiot, but if you do this work day in and day out, you're bound to forget some time.

Summery:
If you need a relatively cheap bag that doesn't carry a whole bunch of lenses and you don't shoot professionally outdoors, this bag will probably work for you.  If you are a hobbyist of any kind, this thing might last you a decade.

This is a great backpack for anyone that has a lot of camera gear they want to take with them. The inside is fully customizable which is great and it is very easy to get your gear out quick when you need to take a photo. The laptop pocket is great and has more than enough room for my 15" MacBook Pro. I do however wish there was a small divider so you could easily put a notebook to write on or something like that. The backpack is made form high quality material and the included rain cover is a great touch.

This easily fits my two Nikons with lenses on and an addition 2 or 3 lenses with room to spare.

product_title: Manfrotto 118 Male Spigot for 2905 1 4 20 Inch Male and 3 8 Inch Male 26mm Long Adapter Replaces 3107 Brass
product_description: Weight 0 09 lbs

reviews.review_body: very good
Manfrotto is Manfrotto
Worked as expected. Inexpensive.
Was the link i needed to complete my project.
I seem to keep finding ways to need these spigots. Manfrotto quality is great.
Perfect for connecting one piece of equipment to another on your lightstand
To paraphrase Popeye, it is what it is. It is very nicely machined. What more do you need to know?
used this because I lose some connectors and works fine. manfrotto always has quality products for me personally and haven't failed me yet.
Very strong and sturdy. They last a long time. Just keep track of the brass pieces that come with it
works as described. Seems durable.
I lost one just like this and it was the exact one I lost.  The product came as described and it wasn't expensive.
When you need em you need em....these are awesome on the Manfrotto 420b convertible mini booms to keep a light head from twisting or turning when mounted in the boom arm position.
A workhorse for me
Great to be able to order attachments to make things work.  Used to connect attachments on a mcam rig for a Ipod
It is what it is for. I had to buy it because it didnt come in the Manfroto 026 Swivel lite tite umbrella adapter. It seems it got lost somewhere during the shipping.
This item is great for a backup adapter or various other tasks that something like this could be used for. I bought this to add to my adapter collection just to have for needed situations.

I don't lose these often, but it doesn't hurt to have a few extra spigots in your camera bag when you are setting up lights in a low-lit wedding reception venue. The added bonus of the hole in the middle makes tightening/securing that much easier. Fantastic upgrade to the older version without the hole
Highly recommended!!

I bought some swivel holders second hand that came with two of these adapters. One of them had the threads wore down on one end. I bought one here to replace the worn down one. It works well but I'm worried that overtime the threads might wear down like the first one.

overpriced but no substitute for this quality item from manfrotto. China knock offs in cheap metal with thread inserts are a problem as the inserts and ends get stuck and they are made of unknown metals and probably have lead content which is toxic.
Maybe it's me but I couldn't install with zero bubbles. But it looks great

I mainly use the 118 Male Spigot to mount light heads on light stands, clamps and even mic stands (with a 3/8 to 5/8" adapter). It also works in the Super Clamp but lacks the hexagonal nut to keep it from turning if you forget to tighten down. The 118 is exactly the same length as the 037 Short Stud (26mm) and thus allows a ball head to sit flash against the Super Clamp.

The 118 is basically a reversible stud and has a 3/8" screw for tripod heads and a 1/4" one flip side for cold shoes and other accessories. Brass is a lot softer than steel and will break if you over-torque. So snug it up but don't muscle it and it will last a very long time.

I can never own too many of these little adapters and they've saved me many times when building a rig to hang an extra light, reflector or camera.

The spigot is a simple device that serves an important purpose.  After acquiring a couple of extra Norman lamp heads I ordered these so I could leave them screwed into the bottom of the heads all the time instead of switching one plug from one head to another. I can also use these on a couple of my radio triggers.

It does what I need it to do without any problems.  How could it not be five stars?

Four clams and change for a double ended brass bolt. I guess the weather was bad this year in those Sino/Italian bronze vineyards. As with all Manfrotto products these are well made and well finished. I use them for joining magic arms and other photo rigging. Take care; all of these style studs are made of brass or bronze, as these materials  are inexpensive to mill, and can be designed so as to be unlikely to unscrew themselves in response to otherwise trivial amounts of vibration. But, they are not steel, and they will break, usually leaving a stub of brass inside a rather more expensive piece of equipment. DO NOT OVER-TIGHTEN. Observe reasonable weight limits. When possible, rig safeties for expensive equipment. DO NOT OVER-TIGHTEN.

Don't skimp on these things. You will pay for it in the future if you do. Manfrotto makes the best ones I've found and always turn to them when I need more. Very well made compared to some of the knock offs I've gotten as part of different kits before.

product_title: LensCoat Raincoat RS for Camera and Lens Medium Rain Cover Sleeve Protection Navy LCRSMNA
product_description: Protects From Rain Snow Salt Spray Sand Easy Access to Camera Controls and Lens Cinch Straps adjust cover length by folding the material over itself and keep cover snug No Dedicated Eyepiece Required Made in the USA

reviews.review_body:
Incorrect product description.
This rain coat is ONLY for larger cameras.
Not for midsize.
Hard to zoom on my 70-200 when the RainCoat is on properly. In order to use the zoom, I have to leave the velcro pieces unattached. Repels snow quite well though.

I wanted a rain cover that wouldn't tear, was simple in design, and could be used with a tripod. Simple right? Nope. Most of these things are cheap in quality. I would sooner use a plastic grocery bag than pay $15 for something that is just as durable, yet comes with velcro and elastic. Others have weird sleeves or odd sizes which make them awkward to use, and very few seem to allow you to use a tripod in both horizontal and vertical orientation. This design and construction is great, yet could probably cost about $20 less. I would say it is overpriced, but I did buy it and this is photography, so I'll let you be the judge. I was planning a trip into the Canadian back country which is known for rain, and I didn't want to get ll the way out there and not have a properly functioning rain cover. That is the only reason I paid for this. Otherwise, just use a plastic bag.
Quality construction and design that makes for great functionality.  My RainCoat kept my camera and lens dry during an all day rain, and I couldn't be more satisfied.

This item is well-made and fits my setup well (Nikon D3200 with 55-300mm lens on tripod).  It's pretty easy to put on and take off.  I have not had the opportunity to use it in foul weather so cannot speak to its "waterproofness" but will update my review once I have.  Very happy with it so far!

I was concerned about this product, wondering if it would be too bulky while shooting, but I was surprised.  We had a heavy slushy snowfall here and I used this cover while I was out in the weather.  It was awesome.  The camera lens stayed dry and I had no issues focusing under the cover.  I am going to purchase another set for my husband's camera. Great product!!

product_title: Manfrotto 165 Ground Level Spreader for Non Spiked Series Tripods Replaces 3155 Black
product_description: The Package Length of the Product is 43 688 centimeters The Package Width of the Product is 13 462 centimeters The Package Height of the Product is 13 462 centimeters Country of Origin ITALY

reviews.review_body: This works fine on my 536 CF sticks, but beware that it can't be used below a certain height. The 536 legs can adjust to go very low, either by selecting the middle "ledge" on the leg locks or by fully removing the locks to go very low. At either of those settings the legs are too wide for this spreader and it will need to come off.
Manfrotto may be great but not this ground spreader. I haven’t even gotten yet to uneven surfaces, having only used it inside my house, and it only seems to make the rig more shaky. Sad.

Manfrotto was purchased by another parent company, since then I have seen a decline in their products which I have been using since the 90's.
This Floor spreader is plastic and will most likely break as it is not a composite gun frame grade of plastic.

I use this for my second tripod which is a VARIZOOM 100mm with a Manfrotto 509HD mounted on it.
The 509HD came from the factory with a broken rosette but Manfrotto sent me one out overnight after a month.
FYI don't email them, call the NJ/NYC number.

I have the Manfrotto tripod legs 755XB and 755X.  These legs spreads far apart so the floor spreaders kept the legs in a "smaller spread" which increases overall height.  My 755 legs having a center column, so the floor spreader gets in the way to collapse the tripod in the "put away" position".  So I would need to take the spreader off at the end of the shoot.  But I think it is best to remove the spreader anyways so the "stretched position" rubber bands does not weaken.

Cons: When moving while shooting, collapsing the legs to move and re-opening the legs, sometimes you need to kick a leg or two to fully open as the spreader foot is not in it's fully rest position.  This is when the spreader is in its smallest diameter position.  I have not used the fully wide diameter position.
Working with it on carpet and grass is another thing.  Carpet, no problem, but on grass, the tripod floats.  I removed the spreader and the tripod was much more stable.

For the price, a good buy.

Despite the overall quality of most everything Manfrotto makes, this is not one of those items.  Purchased this to convert my 75mm mid-level spreader tripod in to a floor spreader.  No dice. The bands that "secure" the feet to the unit, are actually not very secure at all. The result is a flood spreader that loosely flops about and make quick, steady and consistent deployment impossible.  Had to return this one.

No one could tell me the benefits of having a floor level spreader to replace my mid level spreader, but I bought it anyway and it has changed my everyday work for the better.  The tripod deploys much more easily and quickly, and it is much easier to move the tripod from one spot to the next in a one handed operation.

product_description: BESPOKE FIT The MegaGear Premium Leather Camera Case with Battery Access is specifically tailored using high quality leather for the Sony Alpha A6400 18 135mm models for precision fit and coverage ENHANCED PROTECTION Due to its rugged construction and tailored fit this case provides maximal external protection for your camera against bumps dust damage and shock The soft internal layer of padded fabric keeps your LCD and lens safe from scratches along with protecting your camera body FUNCTIONAL ACCESSIBILITY The Ever Ready is designed for efficient photography and accuracy You can access all peripheral ports card slots buttons and the battery without removing your case and attach it to a tripod with the case on CONVENIENT Convenience features allow rapid use of your camera when needed taking that impulsive shoot is as easy as flipping the top cover open Perfect for functional travel and outdoor use STYLISH DESIGN Whether you are a beginner or a seasoned professional photographer you will want these lightweight leather cases at your side combining exquisite ageless leather style with rugged protection

reviews.review_body: I bought it because I thought it was made of leather. It is not badly made, but not with leather. The case is a bit too rigid and does not fit the camera very tight. The color is also like mud, not very pleasing.
Perfect case
Item works perfect. Great to protect body and lens wen thrown in a backpack.
Nice looking case and seemed well made. It just did not fit my camera.

I love this case and its design. It protects the camera and a lens up to the 18-135mm size very well. It has nice soft padding inside and seems very well made too. I like the fact that there is a separate little door to access the battery/SD card compartment so that you don't have to remove the case to swap them out.
However, I am pretty sure it's not genuine leather. It's a nice PU leather-look though.
While I would have liked it to be actual leather (since that is how it is described), I am still happy with it.

reviews.review_body: Advertised as a 3/8 stud, I bought this for my Manfrotto Superclamp. I expected a 3/8 x 16 part. Not so. What I received is metric 10 x 1.5 thread. None of my equipment uses this size so it is useless to me.
worked as advertised

product_title: Rokinon Series II 85mm F1 4 Weather Sealed Telephoto Lens for Canon EF Model Number SE85 C
product_description: Optically constructed of 9 elements in 7 groups 1 Hybrid Asperical Aperture range of F1 4 F22 Uses 72mm filter size Features ultra multi coated glass and 9 aperture blades Angle of view of 28 3 degrees on full frame and 17 7 degrees on APS C

reviews.review_body:
The review of this lens actually gave me very mixed emotions. You probably just said emotions? Yes, and I will explain.

First off here's some info:
My Experience Level: Professional (Successful Photography Business, 30+ Weddings, Thousands of Portraits)
Camera Body: Canon EOS R + EF adapter (needed)

The 1 star for auto focus and image stabilization is due to the lens not having these features. In order for the Camera body to take photos you need to actually go into custom settings and tell the camera "Release Shutter without a Lens attached". Yes, unless it's a Canon lens the body will not even acknowledge it's existence. The lens also does not have mechanical image stabilization. If your camera body does not have digital stabilization I suggest shooting in 3 photo bursts to help with he potential shake/stutter when hand holding.

With that said, lets talk about the lens itself. First of all it looks, feels and functions just as good as Canon's prime lenses. It's heavy, well made and actually looks really cool. The lenses dials have very satisfying click/tap feedback as you change the settings and the focus ring is very very smooth! I was blown away! The biggest con is you must manual focus the lens using the ring. Now, I was terrified at this. I have always auto focused, rarely using the viewfinder to take photos. My screen is always open, max brightness and I tend to always shoot this way. One huge find is that I discovered Canon's manual focus feature to highlight areas that are in sharp focus STILL functions with this lens (picture included with review). That may be a game changer for some, because it actually eliminates a lot of the uncertainty.

With all that said I can now bring up the mixed emotions. First off, the lens takes absolutely stunning photos. I can't really stress how beautiful the bokeh actually is. I knew for a very long time if I wanted the creamiest, smoothest bokeh a (1.2 or 1.4) 85mm was the excalibur for portraits. The issue is Canon's version of these lenses are literally between $2300 and $2800 dollars. So, basically you're paying $2000+ more dollars for auto focus/stabilization and lens features syncing up with Canon's faster point/shoot system. Nothing against Canon, because I know they price their professional lenses with market markup taking into consideration the "returns" the lens will give. However, in my case and for many after the pandemic $2700 is just way too much money for me right now. I am so happy with the lens, and plan on putting it to great use this year!

product_title: OM SYSTEM OLYMPUS LH 55B 9 18 mm MFT Lens Hood
product_description: Package Dimensions 11 43 cms L x 7 874 cms W x 4 064 cms H Product Type Camera Lenses Package Quantity 1 Country Of Origin China

reviews.review_body: The price point and lack of inclusion with the 12-50mm lens is just a slap in the face. Earth to Olympus, you still aren't Canon or Nikon.
No longer need

Strong construction that fits perfectly onto the lens.
Superior matte finishing inside and out. However, as it does not reverse mounting, it does make lens cap removal/attachment a bit cumbersome.
Arrived quick and as described
fits perfectly and goes on with no trouble
Fits perfectly glad I didn't get the cheep knock off
Kind of a rip off in general due to it be OE, but the only one made for this WA lens.  FYI, it was more expensive on E-bay!
Given Olympus does't include with their lenses I had to purchase it separately for my 12-50mm.  Come on Olympus!!!  It does the job!

Pay the extra money for the Olympus hood. The Olympus Hood for 9-18 mounts correctly and stays in place like it should. I could not find the lens hood for the 14 to 42 so I bought the Rinbow off brand. It will not mount on the lens, a complete waste of money.

I bought this lens shade for my wide angle Olympus zoom lens even though there are some other generic ones because I have read that the generic ones don't fit as well.  For my other lenses, I bought generic lens hoods for half the price and they work well.

I bought this to use with the 12-50mm lens. Olympus recommends this hood for that lens.  If fits, but:

- the hood is too wide to shade the 12-55mm lens effectively

- the hood does not mount reversed for storage

I use the hood because it does provide some protection against hitting things with the lens, but otherwise it is pretty useless. I think it is pretty lame that Olympus does not have a proper hood for the 12-50mm lens.

This is a relatively cheap lens hood, and it serves its purpose just fine.  The only reason I'm docking it a star, and people are welcome to bash me for this, is for the simple fact that I have to buy it at all.  Plain and simple: the hood should come with the lens.  Period.

Good value. Some have complained that lens shade does not fit properly and when installed is at an angle. At first I had the same experience but if you apply a bit more pressure the lens hood snaps and locks into position perfectly aligned. It is easy to snap on or off once you realize how it works.

Olympus really should include the hood with its lenses, but they don't.
This does what we expect. A necessary addition.

This lens hood fits just right for the 14-150mm, and there is no vignetting, came quickly (as always) from Amazon so I have no complaints in this regard.  However, given the hefty price of the very nice lens, the lens hood should have been included with the lens.  This represents just another example of Olympus (and a few other name brand optics makers)  predatory behavior with their customer base.  Shame on them for this approach to their loyal customers.

I once made the mistake of buying a cheap knockoff lens hood that didn't fit properly. The genuine Olympus lens hoods fit perfectly. So it's worth paying for this lens hood if you've already paid for the 9-18mm lens which isn't a cheap lens.

However, one can't help but point out the cheapness of Olympus not including the lens hood with such an expensive lens. This is just a piece of plastic that probably costs only a few cents each to manufacture once the mold is already designed.

Not much too say.  Works great and looks good on my new Olympus 12-50 ED Lens.  Not going too complain that Olympus didn't provide it with my lens as I think 1 million others have already complained about this.....though it should!!

I bought this hood for my M.Zuiko 12-50 mm kit lens, for which it is specified. It fits fine and clicks into place very reassuringly. Yet, for some unknown reason, Olympus did not design this hood to fit reversed over the front of the lens. So, when I pack it up into the lens pouch or camera pouch, I have to fiddle with it or it will go in sidewise. That means it has to be packed in the deployed position. Sloppy design work, Olympus. Expect better from you.

This lens hood is well made, but the pricey lens it fits really ought to include the hood and a pouch instead of requiring separately searching for yet another "option."  Trying to track down all these often scarce and overpriced little extras can be extremely time consuming and tedious.  Come on Olympus, do the right thing for your customers!

A minor drawback of this hood is it won't attach to the lens when reversed, as can be conveniently done for storage purposes with other similar hoods on bayonet mounts.  The 9-18mm lens it fits is so compact, easing storage with the hood even a small amount might make sense.

One thing this hood has that I don't see on the much less expensive knockoffs is an optically dampening coating on the inner portion of the plastic hood (a dark matte type surface to reduce reflective glare.)  That's what you get for the higher price, for what it's worth.

This hood functions as expected but (at least on my Olympus 12-50mm weather-sealed lens, on a OM-D E5) doesn't fit completely well. When I put it on the lens it remains slightly tilted and does not fit quite level, as one would expect from such a relatively expensive item from the same, original manufacturer of the lens. Seems to work well in spite of this though.

UPDATE: just noticed the "clicking" part in other reviews, and installed the hood properly. Now it fits perfectly, I just hadn't noticed that detail earlier and was afraid of forcing this plastic piece onto the lens and damaging it, my mistake! No more complaints!

Hood purchased for the mu43 Oly 9-18mm lens.  Initially purchased a petal style hood here at Amazon (?Mennon).  Vignetting at 9 to ~11mm.  The squarish shape "Leitz" style is functional for this wide angle lens.  Aesthetically I prefer the "old school" shape.  In this case function follows form.  Get the best of both.  4 stars only because imho the hood is overpriced.

Bit of a niggle with Oly.  Unlike the Panasonic Lumix mu43 lens purchased, Oly does not include a hood or lens bag.  Expensive after purchase options that should be included in these +$500 lens.  There is a non OME very similar looking hood made in China (probably from the same plant) that sells for ~$15usd.  Not wanting to risk another oops I spent the extra few dollars here at Amazon.  Lucky day, it was a "Gold Box" special item.
Fit perfectly on my lens and it has a distinct snap to it when attached correctly.  Great price as well.
It is so stupid of Olympus to make us buy lens hoods when Panasonic/Canon/Nikon include them.  Of course it fits right and works right . . . it better after you make me buy it separately.

This lens hood is very well designed. It fits on the outer part of the lens with a click, such that its rectangular shape, optimized for maximum possible shading, is exactly aligned. The lens does not rotate when focused. Furthermore, the hood fits over a filter, instead of being screwed into it. Thus it does not create vignetting when used together with a filter. (I advise using only very slim filters as this is such an ultra-wide lens.)

It should, however, have been included free with the lens, plus a lens case... Available lens "pouches" are too big, and don't offer much protection. Come on, Olympus--you used to include lens hoods and sturdy lens cases for OM lenses!  Especially for a $600 lens...

product_title: Fotodiox Lens Mount Adapter Compatible with M42 42x1mm Screw Mount Lenses to Sony E Mount Cameras

-to connect a Pentax SMC Takumar lens with M42 screw mount- to a Sony Alpha 6000 E mount. One does not need to remove the inner ring.

Well, it's a well built adapter. Both M42 and NEX mounts are built with metal. Support full frame A7r & A7 & A7s(maybe more on way). The NEX mount is a little loose compared with authentic lens such as 2470 FE, but acceptable.
It is cheap and it works perfectly with my Super-Takumar f1.4 50mm lens.  I have serial number 4109955, so I think a late Model 2.

It was compatible with my camera body (Sony NEX 5T) and lens (Helios 44-3), however, for some reason, I could not adjust the focus ring of my lens when screwed on. It would just unscrew every time I tried to adjust it. There was nothing I can do to fix it and I even reached out to the manufacturing company and they said that there was nothing I can do as well. I read online that this issue usually happens with cheaper adapters, so I bought an adapter that was a little bit more money and it works perfectly. I say if you need an adapter as soon as possible and don't have the luxury of returning the item, don't take the risk with this one. It's pretty cheap though, so not a big risk in terms of money.

Great adapter! It is sturdy, solid and both mounts are well-built. I have not had any issues with mounting M42 lenses and the Sony E mount fits nicely on the A7. Very happy to be able to use my old lenses again.
This adapter arrived prior to expected date and is of excellent quality.  It works really well with a 44mm F2 lens on the Sony A6000 E-Mount.  Very satisfied and was a great price.
It adapter my m42 lenses to my A7 II, and has a snug fit on both the body and the lense.  I like it a lot.

This is basically a metal extension tube with the Sony E mount at one end and M42 threads at the other. Mine attached solidly to the Sony Nex-6, with maybe a little play. Several of the other reviews wrote about problems with various Takumar lenses not mounting correctly. I had no problem mounting either older "Super Takumar" lenses or the (relatively) newer "Super Multi-coated Takumar" lenses. The lenses included a 55mm f2.0, 35mm f3.5, 105mm f2.8, and 135mm f2.5.
It is quite good and good quality, it fits good for my vintage lens

The M42 lens adapter seems well-made and a solid fit on the lens and camera. I'm currently using it with a Sony a6000 and a classic Vivitar Series 1 lens, Great fun to use an old lens on a  newer high tech camera.
