Muy buen producto hasta ahora, excelente acople, tanto a la cámara Sony a7 M3 como al lente Helios Zenit 58mm. Recomendable.
I bought this for my Sony a6300 and the set of 3 vintage lenses I have are working perfectly.

Works as expected. Arrived quickly. Build and machining is quite up to par for the price. I have not had any issues attaching any of my m42 lenses. I currently use an SMC taKumar 35 3.5 and a mamiya sekor 55 1.8 on my Sony a7. Both lenses sit flush to the adapter and function as expected.
Let's face it this is a piece of metal with threads on one end and another set of threads on the other that's pretty much it and it does what I'd like it to do not much else to say.

I bought this adapter to mount a Mamiya-Sekor 55mm f/1.4 lens to my Sony NEX-5N. At first I was very disappointed, since when screwed all the way on to the adapter, the f-stop adjustment tab was on the bottom of the lens. This was not a very convenient place for that to be! Then I  noticed there are three small screws on the side of the adapter. An easy fix to the problem was to remove the screws and rotate the two parts of the adapter to a new position and re-tighten the screws. Now the f-stop adapter is located where it should be - on top of the lens. It took all of 5 minutes to fix, so I still give it 5-stars.

Tried this with the 50mm f1.4 S.M.C. Takumar from my old Spotmatic II, but it is not compatible. These later lenses have a tab in the mount that communicated the aperture to the setting to film camera bodies, and this tab contacts the inside of the adapter before the lens is fully screwed in. In fact, trying to install the adapter scraped some of the black paint from the tab.

However, it does work with the older Super Takumar lenses, as these lack the aperture tab.

To make the design compatible, the adapter must be modified to remove the flange that presses in the diaphragm pin. This is no problem as long as one switches the lens to "man".

Problems are likely with any lens that has an enhanced variation of the M42 base. Other than that, it's a well made adapter.

I ALMOST returned this! I acquired the Takumar 50 1.4 (not the super, but the super-multi-coated one) and this was cheap enough to give it a try. Upon screwing on, the aperture tab collides with a lip in this adaptor preventing the focus ring from moving. I almost sent it to a friend to cut some metal off! It wasn't obvious, but using a 1/16 hex tool I took the m42 thread out and the spacer simply fell out, and it now works flawlessly!

I have only one issue with the Fotodiox Lens Mount Adapter Compatible with M42 lenses. It has an inner ring that compresses the "stop down/wide open" pin on the back of Pentax Takumar lenses. If the opening of this ring was just slightly larger the pin wouldn't get compressed and the Auto/Manual switch on Takumar lenses would be useful for shooting with manual focus. Eventually I will get this adapter on a metal lathe to fix this problem, making the adapter far more useful with Takumar lenses. Otherwise it is very well manufactured.

This M42 to E mount adapter works perfectly for my M42 lenses. I use them with my Helios 44-2 58mm f2 and Jupiter 11 135mm f4 lenses. The adapter works for Full Frame without any vignetting on my Sony A7S II full frame mirrorless camera. Solid build and fits snug. Would recommend because I have two of them :D

The Fotodiox M42 adapter works will with  Pentax and most other brand lenses that have a automatic diaphragm with a control pin on the  back of the lens mount, with the Sony A7R.  The adapter includes a seat on the inside that pushes the pin in so that the diaphragm is always closed to your set shooting aperture.  The camera sets the correct exposure on using aperture preferred and following additional Sony instructions.  You cannot use the "Manual/Auto" lever on the lens to open the diaphragm using this adapter.  Also, you cannot use preset Zeiss Jena lenses that have a metal rim extending beyond the threaded part of the lens mount because they clash with the seat in the Fotodiox M42 to Sony E adapter.

If you wish to use the Manual/Auto lever to open the diaphragm on your M42 lenses, you may do so by getting the Fotodiox Pentax K-mount to Sony E adapter and adding a Pentax M42 to K  adapter.  Then you may focus with the lens wide open and then move the Manual/Auto lever to close the lens to shooting aperture.

Similarly, if you wish to shoot with older (1950's) preset Zeiss Jena lenses, use a Fotodiox Pentax K-mount to Sony E adapter and a Pentax M42 to K mount adapter ring, and these lenses will fit perfectly.

Note added:  Upon seeing comments on reflections from the rear of the front ring, I mitigated this problem by using a black Sharpie pen on the back of the chrome ring.  If you wish, you could remove the chrome ring and use flat black primer paint.  Finally, I have had no trouble using this adapter with nine different SMC and Super Multi-Coated Pentax lenses.
All my M42 lenses fit and were able to achieve infinity focus. Including an 8 blade Pentax 50mmf1.4 lens.

This works as stated, is well machined and cleanly finished.  It is simply a tube of the correct length to allow for the use of Pentax screw mount lenses (M42 type lenses) on a Sony NEX e-mount camera.  It clicks into place on the camera body smoothly and snugly.  Then the M42 lenses screw into the adapter equally smoothly.  However, you should check each time you shoot to make sure the lens is snug.  It tends to loosen in use.  This is especially true of long lenses.  The problem is that the long lenses are heavy and you will, most likely, find yourself handling and carrying the camera by the lens if it is long (e.g. 135mm or 200mm etc.) to keep the weight off of the camera body lens flange.  Additionally, you may find the older lenses are a bit stiff to focus if they have been out of use for a while (very likely!).  As you focus, you may accidentally find yourself unscrewing the lens.
Very good adapter, all metal. It does focus to infinity, no problem with my Spiratone 28mm 2.8 lens, I've heard there's issues with Helios lenses but easy to hack. Recommended

This adapter seems to be of very high quality.
Initially I was disappointed because all my lenses were with their markings upside down when attached to the adapter. Fortunately there are good people like the reviewer before me who pointed out how to reposition the lens by loosening the adaptor screws.

The older Takumar users should be aware that this adapter will not allow the aperture ring to be rotated as it has a protruding inner ring. I suspect this is the specification and Fotodiox built the item according to it - I have only one other adapter (for EOS) which does not have the protruding ring on the inside. Now I have to work with the Takumar by using the M42->EOS->NEX route.
Other than that - no complains.

I'm giving the adapter 5 stars as I think it is wonderful for the price.

I attempt to find Fotodiox adapters whenever I can. They are very accurately machined, nicely finished and feature a button-type lens release instead of a simple tab. So far, I have adapted nine of the most highly-rated prime lenses to my ILCE Sony 7R and the results are spectacular. I say that, because I have been using medium format cameras since 1941 and the results I am getting from my Sony surpass the shots out of my Rolleis, Hasselblad and Mamiya medium format equipment. Not only is the shadow detail greater, but the smoothness in even tones, like the sky, exceed that taken with film cameras. If Fotodiox maintain their present high standards of quality control at their reasonable price points, they will dominate the market. I know something about marketing. I was the Ad Mgr for a Fortune 500 company when I was 28. Of course, I've been retired now for some 30 years. Keep up the good work!

This fits nicely on the NEX 5n, and seems well made. The M42 screw-mount can be rotated by loosening the three small set screws so that the lens might be oriented to one's liking, as I needed to do with an old Takumar 50mm f1.8. The combination works well and it is certainly fun to play with the old lenses again, using the 5n's excellent MF capabilities and the wonderful bokeh and shallow DOF inherent in the lens's design. I will probably get the equivalent Canon FD adapter as well. I believe that anyone with decent older MF lenses and a NEX ought to make the very small investment in one or more such adapters, it really is a lot of fun.

Got this microSD card out of curiosity when it was on sale.  The card is advertised as a Class 10/U3 card, so it should maintain at least 10MB/s when writing data.  Running Crystal Disk Mark shows reasonably good numbers for sequential reads/writes which compare somewhat favorably to a 4-year-old 64GB Samsung Pro microSD card I had sitting around.

However, trying to transfer a large 3.5GB data file to my Strontium Nitro A1 revealed a problem.  The card appears to provide advertised write speeds with relatively small files, but continuously writing to the card shows that write speeds can drop to 1MB/s or even less, as I witnessed in my tests.  This can present a problem if you bought this card thinking that you can use it to capture long running videos.  Running the same test against my old Samsung card shows that it does not suffer from the same issue.

Bottom line: Do not buy if you must have a microSD card that can maintain class 10/U1/U3 speeds at all times.  It should be an OK card if your typical usage involves mostly reads or if your writes are limited in size and duration.  The card appears to stall after only a few seconds of writing.

I was looking for a high-end 16GB micro SD card to use as the hard drive in my Raspberry Pi. The Raspberry Pi is an extremely tiny computer that measures ~about 5"x3"x2". These small but powerful computers are used for things like controlling  automated Christmas light displays; I use mine for the  graphic intensive application called Kodi. This micro SD card was purchased in late June, 2019. The Raspberry Pi does not have a traditional hard drive, they're very Compact and use a Micro SD card to function as the hard drive. So I was looking for a very high-end card of relatively small size today, as it's a critical repository for the operating system. I've had this for a few months now and I'm noticing more and more fatal errors reading and writing to the drive. I pulled the micro SD card and deep formatted it multiple times trying to resolve the air. I only paid about $6 for this but I was willing to spend more to get a very stable reliable Drive. This is not the drive. Although relatively small by today's standards, it probably would work fine for holding images and video and stuff, but again 16GB they pretty much put in a box of Cheerios today. Storage has gotten phenomenally cheap. So I'm searching for a better flash drive, typically Samsung drives have been Rock Solid I may go that direction.

Never a failure, always works first time and never any issues with bad sectors and lost data even after using it for almost a full year so far.  I keep my eyes out for another similar sale because I am hooked on this card. Would I buy it again -- you betcha !!

Too small for my compact sized Pentax binoculars.  Difficult to pack binoculars into the case and it would not be easy to close, even if it fit the binoculars.  A waste of money.
I liked this pretty well.  I use it on a Nikon Monarch 3 6-24x50 and it fits just fine
The magnetic catch would work well, however my 10x42 Alpen binos are too large for this.
Great value, fits my 3-9x40 and protects it well.  Like the strap for easy removal and the ability to clip it to something .
This cover works great on my rifle scope. Protects it as well as the plastic cups that fit on the ends and is much easier to remove and store
I think that this item could be different. I didn't read very well the description of this item, so this is not for Eagle Optics Binocular.
What is there to say. Inexpensive, easy to put on and take off. Excellent protection for your scope, not only for the end lenses.
I returned these as I did not think they were very well padded.  Bought the Eagle Optics 42mm Ranger Case which seems very sturdy and well padded.
FABULOUS FITS MY FUGINON 8X32 BINOCULARS PERFECTLY.

The elastic band stretched out and does not hold the cover in place with just a couple days of use. The magnets are not strong enough to keep the flaps closed. I do not recommend purchasing this item.
I have these covers on all of my scopes. I tried other cheaper covers, but they didn't fit as perfectly as the Carson covers. It provides the scope protection I wanted without being cumbersome.
works good
I have used this for a few months now and am very happy with it.  The quality of the material is excellent and I am confident it provides good protection for my scope.

The case over all is made really well, but I have Vortex Bino's which are not cheap and it is too small. Even though it says they should fit on the description. The flaps are not long enough and the magnet isn't strong enough to keep it closed.
great product and awesome protection
Fits my 4x32 Leapers perfectly. I hate the pop open covers & this one fits my 12" long scope like a glove. Looks & feels well made - time will tell

I bought two. When I upgraded to 10x binoculars I found that they did not fit well. But on the 8x pairs they work well, fold out of the way when looking, fold over the lenses when walking...a good product.
This did not fit the item for which it was intended.  It is kind of cheesy, but probably will work.  It probably won't be effective in dense brush, but would serve in open areas.

I should have listened to the other reviews, it is not big enough to fit my binoculars even if they said it would.  it does not stay on, and I am always fumbling with it.  only good thing is when you are not using it, it at least keeps the dust off of the lenses...
The Carson ScopeArmor Rifle Scope Cover (BA-10) does a fine job of protecting the scope on my .177 pellet gun.
i use it on a Bushnell ERS and it doesn't cover the turrets all the way but keeps the glass safe.

Bought this for a wet, cold and wind bird watching trip to Rockport MA. Unfortunately it is just a little too small for my Nikon monarch binoculars and I have work to get it to stay on. Love the idea but wish I had gotten a slightly larger version.

Substantial enough to protect scopes. Feels like neoprene with a soft covering. Stretches to accommodate scopes of various lengths. Handy straps on either end make it very easy to slip on and off. A good item.

First, I will say that the delivery was extremely fast!  However, the product is not as advertised on the Carson Optics manufacturer's website.  The informational video states that the cover flap is secured, using 3 strong magnets.  The product I received contains only a single (and not very strong) magnet.  As a result the cover flap barely secures hold to the body of the cover.  The fit, materials and craftsmanship seem to be of pretty high quality, but the functionality is not what what was advertised.

Runs a little large but still fits a standard 3 X 9 X 40 scope. Larger scopes will improve the fit. Very durable neoprene material that should hold up. The price seemed fair. The lanyard on the end is somewhat useless I took it off.

This is a great product. I have yet to find a rifle scope set up it doesn't work on. it definitely protects the scope, and part of the rifle, usually the action, from dust, dirt, nicks and scratches. And to a certain extent bumps as well. The only improvement I can think of is if it came in camouflage. That certainly is not enough of an issue to proven me from buying six of them. 'Nough said?

Cover doesn't really hook on either end - more of an envelope with an open bottom that goes down on top of the scope. Covers the whole scope. Good for protecting scope in the safe from other scopes and dust. Don't know if I'd carry it into the field - not overly secure on scope. Good price though.

I like the concept of this scope cover.  It pulls on and off very easily and provides nice protection to the scope with its cushioned neoprene material.  However, these are made for hunting scopes with small turret knobs and don't fit well over large, exposed tactical turrets.  If your scope has covered turrets that are less than 3/4" tall, this would be a great field or storage cover.  It just didn't work well with my Vortex Viper PST and it's tall turrets.

Armor and shock absorbing might be a little over the top. It's stretchable neoprene and does protect the scope from scratches and dust. Looks good and I like the detachable strap. I use it for a Redfield Widefield, 13" scope, and it fits good. For ten bucks and change, I'll buy another when I need one.

I like the magnetic closure and the light weight.  Not sure why they make it so tight for my 8X42 binoculars.  I am pulling/stretching it over them, hoping the wrap will loosen up/stretch a bit and fit better with time.
Will fit an AR with Burris MTAC scope but no magazine.
Love storing my binoculars in this and going through the woods, rain, etc... this protects them! When it come time to buy some Nikon binoculars I purchased the same case as my Carson's come in

I did not have a good feeling when I opened the package and saw my purchase. It seemed that the material used in construction was not worthy of the price. It fits my scope and it looks nice. However, the material suggests that it might not hold up to being carried to and from the range and the abuse of hunting. If I had the opportunity to touch this product before buying, I would not have purchased it. I will do a follow-up later and if an apology is warranted? I will give it.

Really nice wrap (not a case), and a very good concept.  Will fit most 8x25, 10x25, 8x32, 10x32, but 8x42 or similar will NOT fit.  I have the Celestron Nature DX 8x42, which are really small for an 8x42, and they don't quite fit.  The flap will just barely close, but will pop open from the pull of the binocular neck strap.  8x32 or smaller, you'll love it!  If you want more protection, Carson also makes another version (larger) that covers the sides as well... that version will fit up to 6" tall binoculars.
Hope this helps!

Like it, but the flip part of the cover is not very strong, and I actually had the strap slip out on one side.  Fortunately a friend saw it and we were able to catch it in time.  I readjusted the strap, and haven't had a problem since.  Just a practical caution to check your strap before going out in the field.

The Carson Binocular case was a true disappointment. Needing to replace a case for my Nikon Monarchs, I found only this product. It should not be called a "case". It's not even a sleeve. Though it may have some value in protecting bins from shock damage, moisture and dust (and dropping) are not addressed in this design. It is simply a wide strip of neoprene with tapered ends that fasten with a magnet. My binoculars, which are listed among the ones stated on the packaging for which this "case" is suited, are apparently a bit too long for the magnetic closure to work reliably.
The "case" is intended to remain attached to the bins while using them. Poor idea as the end of the "case" near the eyepieces interferes with breathing as it falls in front of the nose and mouth.
Some may find a use for this item as added protection in combination with a true case when traveling. But it did not serve my purpose.

This is not the case for you if you want full coverage of the binocular.  I was simply looking for something to cover up the lenses that I could quickly deploy.  This fits the bill for what I needed it for.  It seems a little tight right now, but I'm hoping it loosens up a bit as I use it.  The magnet is a great and quiet option.

I like this better than the lens covers that came with my Nikon Monarch binocular.  It is for the next bigger binocular than I have so there is a lot of extra space in it and it has fallen off of my binocular out in the field a couple of times but I don't think that would be an issue if I had the correct size binocular for this case.  It will keep mist and rain off of the eyepieces and protect both ends of the binocular when it is stuffed in a backpack.  I think the description., or maybe it was their website, mentions that the closure mechanism is magnetic so quieter than Velcro but might interfere with pacemakers.
Works great; I use a regular scope instead of binocs; this allows me to keep it in the tool box.

Being an avid bird watcher, I am always looking for new ways to refine my hobby.  Carson's BinoArmor saves me a tremendous amount of time when I am out in the field.  I no longer have to bother with taking the time to take off my lens caps on my binoculars. The magnetic flaps give me very quick access to viewing birds while at the same time keeping my lenses safe from any dust, scratching and debris.  The magnets are also terrific as they are very quiet and do not scare off the birds. Having a pair of 8x42mm binoculars, fitting them into the BinoArmor wrap was not an issue at all.  I would highly recommend to this product to anyone looking for a new and innovative way to protect their binoculars.

I bought this to use with my 8x32 Binoculars . My wife had purchased a set of Carson HD-ED Binoculars that came with this case and it worked so well that I purchased this for my older binoculars. The case can be used with or without lens caps. I choose to forego the caps and rely on this new case. The case is easy to install and fast and easy to use. Open the case and have instant access to your binoculars. The case is 5 inches wide so it fits a wide variety of binoculars including my Dad's old WWII Pair. This is a revolution in binocular cases for those who want instant use of their binoculars.
The magnets are too weak.Keeps popping open with my Bushnell 8x42 binoculars.

Bought these even though I knew they would slightly small for the 50mm series Bushnells I intend to use them on.  These are made for 42mm lens so they don't completely protect the larger lens, but they will provide adequate protect for light use because they cover more than 75% of the lens.

The fabric is some sort on neoprene and appears to be durable enough to withstand the use that I'll give these to set up my telescope and occasional range use.  I'd recommend a different product and/or using the original lens covers if you expect your binoculars to be exposed to more rigorus conditions outdoors.

My second one from the same supplier, these are a great fit for 10-12 inch scopes. Has a convenient pull tab on one end (towards you) and a elastic piece with snaps to wrap around barrel and forearm. With a sling attached, one does not have to worry about losing the scope armor, you just pull tab and let it flop to the side. Innovative and well priced, protects one of the most important components of your firearm.
Bought this one to cover a Rimfire Leupold scope on a ruger 10/22. Fits a little loose but works to protect the scope in my safe. Does what I wanted.

At first I wasn’t sure about the design.
I’m extremely happy I decided to buy this cover.
The wrap around design is great. It really keeps your scope protected in the field..
I will eventually buy more for my guns I use in the field hunting.

product_title: AmScope M100C LED SP14 E 40X 1000X Student Biological Field Microscope with LED Lighting Camera Slide Preparation Kit
product_description: Five magnification settings 40X 100X 250X 400X 1000x Sturdy metal framework 640x480 USB camera for capturing photos and video LED light uses 3 AA batteries included or plug transformer Includes slide preparation kit with both prepared and blank slides

reviews.review_body: no manual download it and print it out tried the camera hooked it up loaded cd software to the computer opened program it said not all was loaded on the computer a fatal error message popped up the computer shut down had to reload windows 10 big mistake buying this
Not good. Can’t see anything
Worthless junk and not worth the money. One of the lenses arrived broken. Instructions are home made. Too bad I missed the return window.

I guess I shouldn't have expected much from a microscope that was only 120.00. I was very disappointed in it. The camera was really bad, super blurry, no instructions on how to install correct software. Just a huge disappointment. Back to the drawing board to find a decent one at a decent price for my class.
Well made

My kid is back in love with science after using this microscope for his experiments and can't put it down, and I love it as well, specially the camera which send beautiful views to our computer without problems.
My 9 year old lives it. Camera works well. One issue was that light plug is lose where cable meets device causing flicker. This could become a problem rewuiring return. Plug faces operator position.
Total and utter crap. Opened the box, clear as day one of the lenses was missing.  Cheaply made. Directions were a joke. Avoid this product, save yourself the time of having to return it.
Awesome microscope. My daughter loves the ability to watch it on her computer. We’ve actually put things under the microscope and printed cool pictures!

product_title: MegaGear Nikon Coolpix P900 P900S Ultra Light Neoprene Camera Case with Carabiner
product_description: Neoprene Tailored to fit this MegaGear neoprene camera case is specifically tailored to fit the Nikon Coolpix p900 p900s achieving that desired perfect fit Protective crafted from scratch free soft durable and padded neoprene material to provide maximum protection Fast and convenient a durable carabiner lets you clip your camera to your backpack belt or waistband for quick and convenient access when needed The neoprene material is flexible Outdoor or travel protects your camera and lens from dirt scratches dust bumps and moisture while traveling or outdoors Bold vibrant colors comes in a variety of fun unique colors to choose from Choose the color that expresses your style and passion

reviews.review_body: The case us beautiful buy is very difficult to put câmera inside it. Its too tight
Exactly what I needed. Fits my P900 like a glove.

product_title: Tiffen 67HTCGND6 67MM Digital HT Grad ND 0 6 Titanium Filter
product_description: helps even out exposure in difficult lighting situations High light transmission charachteristics Light weight metal mount hardened coatings for better durability Matte Black anti reflecting inner ring

reviews.review_body:
I love using my Zeiss Touit 12mm on my Fuji X-E2, and I'm often shooting outdoors in daylight.  While the camera produces images with a great deal of dynamic range, especially at lower ISOs and the lens allows such lower ISOs, I'm always looking for ways to produce better images.  Using a graduated ND filter allows me to offset the inherent brightness of the sky and focus exposure on the rest of the scene.  It doesn't give me more dynamic range per se, rather it allows me to use what I have where I want to use it.  This is the real benefit of this (and other graduated ND filters), which cannot be replicated in post processing (you can darken the sky, but that's not the entirely point).

This particular filter works well in this regard.  It stays clean, rotates smoothly but not too easily, and it's easy to align with my lens (typically in landscape rather than portrait orientation).  It's also clear and free of any color cast (thus the neutral in ND) and readily holds on to a lens cap.  It's not perfect, as I'd prefer a slightly thinner profile (while still holding on to a normal lens cap), a black color, and a clearer indication of orientation.  Those faults don't impact my images, so I'm rather forgiving.

Pros:
One of the remaining filters that cannot be replicated in post processing (this does far more than darkening skies)
Clear and free of color cast
Stays clean and smudge free
Rotates smoothly but stays in place

Cons:
Pricey (when over $100, but a better deal when $80 or so)
Could be thinner (I didn't see vignetting on my 12mm lens) and grey color an odd decision

I'd prefer the B+W XS-Pro to this, but I got this for quite a bit less ($75), but there's a lot to love here.

In my opinion Tiffen HTs and B+W F-Pros (the 702M) are the best grads out there, for those of us who don't have time to fiddle with (and keep a grip on) rectangular filters. Most of my filters are Hoyas, but their grad is not great quality with some color cast, and it's also a 1 to 3 stop which is weird, so I'll strictly compare those first two.
The disadvantage of this Tiffen is that it uses a somewhat outdated version of coatings that picks up oils and whatnot, and fights a bit when you try to clean it. It does adequately block reflections, the glass quality is excellent, and it has no visible color cast.
The B+W grad has significantly better multicoating but two disadvantages. First, it has a slight reddish color cast in the ND just like most of B+W's constant ND filters. This would be mildly annoying, but not a dealbreaker with just two stops. Second, B+W's mount is 7mm thick, while Tiffen's is 6mm.
The gradient is about the same hardness on both, and neither noticeably degrades sharpness.
If you know mechanical vignetting can occur with a reasonable stack of filters on your lens, get this Tiffen. If that isn't an issue, get whichever you can find cheaper. If you're on a tight budget or don't foresee using a grad often in x filter size, get Tiffen's cheaper uncoated grad, which is oddly the only good-quality Tiffen I've ever tried besides the HTs.
Fabulous filter.
Nice filter
Very good
As expected
Love this filter.
perfect condition.  effect was as expected with my Canon Dslr

A must have filter if you take a lot of landscape photography. This filter will help darken the sky so your pictures will be more evenly exposed. I'm going to be stacking this filter with a hoya hd3 polarizer really soon :)

Really nice filter, good fit and finish. FYI it comes with a (pretty nice) velcro soft pouch instead of the more common hard plastic cases. The product picture here on Amazon is a little misleading, as the transition from ND to clear is not quite as gradual as it appears in the picture.  The picture on the Tiffen website shows the filter more accurately. Even so, the graduated ND effect is still pretty subtle.

i think it's just me nothing wrong witht he product itself, i should've picked not 0.6 as i find it's hard to use, in a dark setting it's accentuates too much and in the middle of the day i don't notice enough of an effect

I bough this Tiffen 52HTCGND6 filter a while back hoping that it would help me to capture spectacular sunset photos however it was not the out come I had hopped for, granted I was using one of the cheapest DSLR cameras you can buy a Nikon D40.  None of the pictures I took with the lens filter impressed me they looked a little dull and lack color in darker side so I have not used it since.

This is a very high quality graduated neutral density filter with premium glass.  I am a professional photographer and have owned dozens of filters over the years but since the advent of digital cameras and photoshop, I have tossed out every filter except the Grad ND and a polarizer.  The grad filter proves invaluable for all kinds of subjects where the sky is way brighter than the rest of the scene.  I use it for family portraiture all the time adnd every pro should use one of these to control exposure accross the scene.  That being said, I have two gripes:  First, there are no points on the edges to mark the center of the gradient, and once it's screwed onto the camera lens, its hard to tell where the gradient begins or ends.  Consequently, I have marked the center-line edges with a dab of white-out for quick reference in the field.  Second, the gradient seems to end abrublty half-way through the filter.  It should be a gradual gradient from dark to light with no definite line down the center.  Though this may be valuable for some subjects, I prefer a "true" gradient with a smoother "fall-off" or transition.

I impress the material of this product is well done. Light weight and strong. The glass is durable but not so easy to clean. The image quality is acceptable. No artifact. However, I found this product yields quite quickly gradual fall-off in the middle-horizontal zone which may suitable for bright sea landscape scenario. I may not recommend this for those who prefer more smooth and soft gradual effect images.
I'm happy to buy this product from Adorama store. The international shipping is incredibly fast! From New York to my home in rural part of Southeast Asia takes only three days without damage.

I rated this 1-star because the image is misleading, suggesting that there is a wide band of gradient transition extending across 2/3 or more of the glass.  The GND of this filter is concentrated only in the top half.  (Tiffen also makes a 'blend' GND which does extend across most of the glass and looks more like the image for this filter.)  For landscapes with tall features (trees, mountains, buildings) extending above the horizon, this filter could be problematic.  Tiffen has excellent glass and checking the specs on their website would be advisable before relying on the images shown on other sellers' sites.

Came with an unsealed container and finger prints.

Also downgrading because Amazon preloaded this form with pre-filled details.

I haven't bought Tiffen filters in the past, mainly because they weren't made of real glass, and I was concerned that my photos would be blurry due to the quality.  Boy, how times have changed.  This filter is made of excellent optical glass, and the construction of the threads is top-quality.  I used this filter extensively on my last outing, and the results were just as good as those from my Hoya and B+W filters.  The price is a little high for a split ND filter, but I think the quality is high enough to deserve it.

After using this filter for a few days, I ended up returning it for two reasons. First, the coatings on it are not nearly as nice as the B+W version of this filter, which I have since ordered in place of this one. When shooting in wet conditions such as spray from waterfalls or sea spray from the ocean, it is very difficult to quickly wipe the lens clean. Where the B+W MRC coated filter wipes clear with one swipe of a microfiber rag. Also, I noticed the filter left horizontal lines in the shadow areas of an image which were very visible upon even slightly boosting the shadows in post processing. The case is not great either as it left a residue on the filter, causing me to have to re clean it every time I took it out of the case. The hard shell cases from B+W are much better. This filter is probably great for some, it's just not for me and my shooting style. Return service was excellent! Refund was issued very quickly.

First of all, the filter is good for what it does: It helps to prevent excessive light on one half of side (top or bottom or your choice by rotating the front ring). This is helpful when you are trying to take photo with bright sky on upper half.  That's all it is used for.  There are few disadvantages. There are some vigination at wide angle (<28 mm or so).  I have to zoom it above 28mm when I use it with 18-200mm Nikor lens that has another neutral filter attached.

Unless you are taking sunset or sunrise photo, it is not that great to use in midday as 0.6 grad is dark enough to prevent too much light from sky. You don't want to have too many of this expensive piece either just because you need more darker (stop down) glass.  The quality is good, but it is only worth the money if you takes lot of picture during sunrise and sunset or sometime pictures with long exposure.

It cost me £95 to import this filter to the Uk.  It is fantastic to use, it prevents bright skys from underexposing the foreground,  because many UK retailers operate a $1 to £1 pound exchange rate it retails for around £180 in the UK, if you can find it in stock anywhere.  It did take a while to arrive,but this kept the postage charges down, and it was well worth the wait for such a classy product. In my humble opinion the Tiffen filters are Crepes Suzette, all the other filters are just pancakes

product_title: SLIK SBH 280E Professional Ballhead with Quick Release Black 618 193
product_description: All metal and easy to use ball head with one knob operation that can handle up to 15 lbs Has dual access bubble levels for perfect leveling of the camera no matter the position of the tripod The SLIK SBH 280E uses industry standard 3 8 tripod mount screw plus a quarter 20 reducer to attach to a wide variety of tripods from SLIK and other brands The SLIK SBH 280E has the same mount lock and ball mechanism as the professional SLIK SBH 280 20mm diameter ball diameter

reviews.review_body: This is my favorite Ball-Head except for the older model Slik (DQ-280) that does not require a clip to unlock the arm. I use this for real-estate photography where getting the angles correct in your images is critical. What sets this Ball-Head apart from other Ball Heads on the market including much more expensive ones, is the large double-bubbles on the side of the head that help in keeping your camera leveled, perfect for those angles ! Not only that, it is pretty compact and light, but not too small where you start pinching your fingers. It does not hold a lot of weight(11 lbs), but for my real-estate camera and lens system that is plenty. I have larger and bulkier heads for my long lenses.

I've had this ball head camera mount for over two years.  I originally bought it with a Slik carbon fiber tripod.  I have no complaints and really like the action, the built-in levels and the thin camera mount.

I recently purchased another for my monopod since I do tend to switch back and forth on occasion.  Honestly, you can't tell the difference between the 2+ year old and the new one.

This head is relatively small and light yet performs very smoothly.  I've never had any issues with creep even with my Canon D40 and a medium-long telephoto.

For those that live in cooler climes; I have used this head in -10 degree weather with no issues.  Couldn't be happier.

product_title: Fotodiox F60 Quick Collapse Flash Softbox 60cm 24in Hexagon for Canon Speedlight and Nikon Vivitar Sunpack Nissin Sigma Sony Pentax Olympus Panasonic Lumix Flash
product_description: Premium grade softbox material with reflective and neutral diffusive material Simple take down tabs on the back of the speedring to release the rods Softbox can be removed and the mount doubles as a umbrella bracket The added grip is great for handholding as well as using on a light stand 24 Month Manufacturer Warranty

reviews.review_body: Great Quality a better Price!
works perfect use it all the time
It's very lightweight, but good value for the price. Does it's job well.
Personally, I find it excellent for portrait work.
This is a great product that did exactly as it said on the "tin"  I have used it now for some critical shoots and it definitely delivered! I've posted one from one of my shoots
Me ha servido.
This was a birthday gift, but my friend said he loved it and would definitely recommend it to anyone else that is looking to buy this product.

I rarely work with an assistant, so this is really nice to use for off camera flash. It's light, folds easy enough. I tend to be pretty rough with my stuff because I'm trying to go so fast...and I have yet to wreck it. I use it 2-4 sessions per day. I've had it for a couple months.
Easy set up and take down.  Produces a very nice light. Quality build even though the handle is plastic.  You just need to be careful not to overtighten the set screws and it should be good.

I have done 4 photo shoots with this unit this week and it is AWESOME! I have attached a few images. All of which were shot with this as the light source, and sun as a hair light. These shots are done only with this one light source. I am shooting a remote SB-700 Speed light. The box has fallen over once, oops. It scraped against an aspen tree, and then fell into hard rocks. NO PROBLEM!~ Love it!

I've only used it a few times, but it's great. I personally like the handle and grip feel. If you have an assistant you won't need a stand. It's comfortable to hold. Not too heavy. It has a well balanced feel when a speedlight is attached. It is good for outdoors too. Not too big for the wind to knock it down. I paired it with a manfroto 5001B stand. It is solid. Quality is good. Setting up and take down is a breeze. I highly recommend this product.

I had never used a modifier with my Canon 430EX II speedlight, but I needed a portable soft box solution that would fit my budget. The Fotodiox F60 Quick-Collapse Flash Softbox sets up quickly (for stand or handheld), and is a breeze to attach the speedlight and the wireless Godox X1R-C receiver to it. Very satisfied with this product!

I need a smaller soft light source for those tight rooms on location.
Lost of plastic used in the construction so not sure how durable this will be.
Light weight and compact when traveling adjusts to different speedlight heights.
Speedlight head tucks well inside the rear of the softbox to prevent light spill.
Most importantly produces beautiful soft light at a great price.
FYI 40 degree hexagon grid avaiable here: [...]

This quick-collapse is really quick. Fast setup, probably takes about 1-2 minutes to get it up and running. You can leave the white panel on when you collaspe it so when you use it again its ready to go. Biggest issue is the handle. Its very thin, hollow inside, and cheap plastic, on first use during tightening it started to separate into two pieces, but its still holding together barely. I know the handle will not last much longer. I suggest if you own a 3d printer to print out one that isn't so hollow.

the nylon soft box itself is well made, I'm just not too crazy about all the plastic framework behind it. Not very solid plastic mounts.  It will do in a pinch, but I should have spent more time researching and money.  I would not buy this model again.
Worst construction ever broke on my first shoot POS!

Nice softbox, good diffusion and dispersion of light. I thought that for the price and weight, the handle assembly would be more sturdy, would've liked to see the handle at least foam wrapped, but better still an aluminum assembly. I'm giving this softbox a 2 star for it's quality, but omitting the other three stars because: (1) The shoe mount broke under the weight of my flash on its first use. The metal screw that holds the shoe in place, sheared off. Luckily I was indoors on carpet, flash is ok. I've already purchased separate metal cold/hot shoe sets and it's fixed that issue, but it shouldn't break 5 minutes into using a new item. (2) The handle is poor quality and has a design flaw: doesn't hold the softbox upright when mounted on a light stand. Maybe on its own, but not with a Canon 580EX, Yongnuo  (3) The stems of the softbox continually detach from their holders.

This is exactly what I was looking for my speedlights. I wanted a portable softbox which I could take with me on location and is quick for setup. I leave both the diffusers on my softbox when I fold it up for storage. When it is time to get it out, simply pull all the rods and insert speedlight handle. I can hand hold this and shoot with another hand.
Like the light quality as well. Build quality is on the average side however I haven't seen any issues after 5-6 uses.

I haven't bought the grid for this yet. But if anyone looking, I found an item with name "Impact Grid For Hexi 24 Speedlight Softbox" . Search for it online.

Obviously a knock off of a Rapid box, but damn is this one nice also.  Having been able to compare the two you can tell there's differences in build quality with the Fotodiox being a little bit more flimsier, and with a heavier plastic build.  But if you want something that functions, and works well I think you will be very impressed with this guy.

Used it for several photoshoots already including a 3 day Indian/American wedding and the results from the softbox are excellent.  The big win factor for the unit is the portability and ease of setup and break down.  I was up and ready in sub 2 minutes setup and break down, and that's a MAJOR plus as a wedding photographer.  This softbox provided excellent lighting for Macro Photography, Portraiture, and more.  I had a 600ex-RT as the light source and had zero issues using both a wired and wireless solution for this device.

For those concerned about the plastic build it can be an issue over time, plastic normally is.  If you don't baby your equipment and expect 3-5 years from it I suggest going for a rapid box.  But if you want good quality lighting, don't baby your equipment, I'm pretty confident with the build quality from this unit you can get a year of shooting with it without worries.  For only $70, the price of this thing can deliver some pretty damn awesome results making it worth the year.
Produces beautiful, even light. It is easy to set up. But the quality of the materials this softbox is made up of can use an improvement. It feels cheapy.

Pros: light. compact. it fits my backpack. Good quality shadows.  good light diffusion. Quick fold unfold operation. Can be operated in single hand while shooting with other. Affordable
Cons:  its plastic and is prone to brake if it hits hard surface.
Actually mine broke even hitting soft grass. I have casted new handle from aluminum and now it will last me forever.

If you are on budget  and you mostly shoot portraits or fashion on location or in run and gun situations than it is no brainer. Get one even if you get more expensive gear later.  you will find yourself using this one quite often.
You can see my photos taken with this light modifier as main light. In single light or two light setups seconds light is bare flash as a kicker light. This octabox gives nice catches in the eyes and smooth shadows on face. Love this thing using it 85% of the time
UPDATE:
tHIS THING IS RAD  i do not know why but this thing is awsome because of  its so light and compact  i end up using it  almost every where and every time.  i like this size  for my dramatic portraits it gives me right type of shadows.  this is good to use in tight spaces  it is good in public spaces  it is good in run and gun situations. i just wish it s handle was  sturdier or of massive plastic or sceletonized aluminum  id also recommend Fotodiox to add adapter options to bowens mount.

About a month or so ago I finally purchased a softbox for my speed light. I have several modifiers for my speed lights but it took me forever to decide on a softbox as I wanted something full-featured, easy to use, and fairly large. I finally settled on this Fotodiox F60 Quick-Collapse 24" Hexagon Softbox. Now I can't judge on how this will hold up over time as I haven't had it long, there are mixed reviews on that. It's in the mid-price range and seems well built for the price, it does have several plastic parts that may or may not hold up well over time. But what I like about it so far is that it's adjustable, I can angle it up, down, wherever I need it. A lot of them don't have this feature for some reason. It's super easy to set up and take down. I don't have to fight with it like traditional softboxes.  It's also adjustable for a variety of speed light sizes and has the ability to fully insert the head of the speed light so there is very minimal light leakage. Finally the light is quite lovely (see test image below), it has an inner baffle (diffusion panel) like traditional softboxes. Another thing missing from many of these types of softboxes. I like the softness it adds but it is another thing between your subject and the light so you will have a little light loss with that. I don't find that a problem, I think I was only at about 1/8 power on the test image below, with a reflector underneath.

product_title: OM SYSTEM Olympus LH 48B Silver Lens Hood for M Zuiko Digital 17mm F1 8
product_description: Silver Design Complements Lens Metal Construction For M Zuiko Digital 17mm F1 8

reviews.review_body:
I'm giving it 1-star because technically it is what it is (a lens hood) and there is no option for 0 stars. $60+ (retail) for a made in China molded piece of metal that probably cost $3 to manufacture and ship. And, it's not included with the purchase of the $500 17 mm lens. There's more.
The lens hood doesn't fit over a filter. You need to put the hood on first and then literally drop a filter onto the lens and wiggle/screw it into place with your fingertips. Incredibly inconvenient if you might want to shoot without the hood, for cleaning or to remove the hood for packing. Also, you cannot use a third-party lens cap with the lens hood. You better not lose that Olympus lens cap. Hmm, I wonder how much a replacement cap costs?
With the hood on, it's extremely difficult to get the lens cap off quickly. You better have very small fingers or else forget it.
I find it hard to believe that this is the only technologically possible lens hood design for the 17mm lens. Combine the above with the gross price mark-up and you have to question if Olympus just wants to stick it to the customer.
I'd love to sit in the office of Olympus' CEO and watch him try to put on and take off the hood, filter and cap. That would be priceless.
An overpriced piece of plastic! It's a shame you need this hood for the Olympus 17MM lens, but it's also a shame that Olympus charges a ridiculous price for a simple plastic ring!

I own a number of the Olympus premium Micro 4/3rds lenses. I have the 12mm, the 17mm and the 45mm. In addition I also own the 9-18 which did not ship with a lens hood. I will be the first to say that for the premium prices we are paying for these lenses they should include lens hoods and storage bags. Sadly, we all know they do not. I have tried a number of the knock off hoods and some of them have been ok and some have been really bad. I bit the bullet and bought all the Olympus lens hoods for each of my Olympus lenses. I figure these are long term purchases and I would like to enjoy the lenses as intended. The LH-48B is like all the others. The finish is excellent, the construction is solid and the fastener screw tightens down a circular clamp that surrounds the lens instead of pressing directly on the lens like a set screw which will scratch it. Is it expensive? Yes. Is it a premium hood? Most definitely. What might be a better solution is to include a cheaper one for free and offer the premium ones for those who want them. I am not sorry I spent the money but I am particular. If you are not you may not see the value. Five star product two star price. I will give it a four stars overall.
no vignetting

I bought The Olympus LH-48B lens hood for my new Olympus 17mm 1.8 lens.  I was shocked that Olympus does not include hoods with their lenses.  However, I went for the Olympus Brand hood since I felt that this would be the most sturdy one.  I am pleased with this hood and the 17mm lens will not go out without this nice sturdy hood on it.  The hood has an interesting thumbscrew that attaches the hood to the lens rather than a threaded hood.  The screw pushes a thin metal bar so that the screw does not touch the lens body.  I like this.  The only downside is that this necessary item should have come with the hood. It is expensive at $69!.

product_title: Tiffen 67mm 812 Warming Filter
product_description: Ideal for portraits or scenics Absorbs blue cast often caused by electronic flash Adds warmth to pale washed out flesh tones Warmer results than Sky 1 A Exclusive Tiffen filter

reviews.review_body: THE 812 WARMING FILTER IS GREAT FOR ANY PHOTO. IT ENRICHES THE COLOR VALUES, MAKING THEM WARM ANDVIBRANT. IT IS NOT JUST FOR WARMERSKIN TONES. THE 812 WORKS WELL FORALL TYPES OF PHOTOGRAPHY, INCLUDING INDOOR AND OUTDOOR, PORTRAIT AND LANDSCAPE. TIFFEN ALSO MAKES A COMBO FILTER, OF THE 812 AND A CIRCULAR POLARIZER. THE COMBO FILTER GOES A STEP FURTHER IN NOT ONLY ENRICHING THE HUES, BUT IN COMBINING IT WITH THE POLARIZER, THEY HAVE SUCCESSFULLYCREATED A FILTER THAT COMPENSENSATES, DISPERSES, EVENS OUT, AND ENRICHES THE LIGHT WITHOUT DETRACTING FROM THE SUBJECT. THE END RESULT IS A POWERFUL, BRILLIANT SUBJECT ( A GREAT PHOTO OF A MEMORY PRESERVED IN TIME ), IN ALL ITS BRILLANCE.
One of the Best filters made.

Extremely well made filter. Its so subtle but so effective. The skin tones actually becomes radiant. The dull and boring look under normal circumstances while clicking people just disappears.
I was introduced to Tiffen by Ken Rockwell and I thank him for that. In fact, I discovered Amazon.com because of Ken.
TOday 90% of my filters are Tiffen and they are at par or better than my previous set of filters at 40% the cost.
I would recommend this to everyone only make sure if you are shooting with direct light in your focus , do buy the COATED ones.
I use it for videos mainly, but it works great for pictures too; its a team player with the ring adaptors and your lenses.
ok deal

good
IT WARMS

The effects that I was looking for. Great filter
delivered as promised
Using a filter, is a different experience. You should try it and get out - shoot, look for the unexpected.

as advertised

it def gives a nice tint to photographs. Makes images look almost a little more vintage. Great for outdoor stuff, or for people who are pale.
Made a huge difference in the color of landscape photos taken during the day. Easy to attach. Very affordable.

As an amateur photographer I don't want to shell out big bucks for filters so I've always been a big fan of Tiffen filters.  Their filters are of good quality and the price is good for us amateur photographers.
works good
Purchased as a gift.
I like this product; for film photography.
I generally prefer to shoot with a warming filter to kill that slight bluishness present with flash or outdoor daylight. If it is a bit too warm, it is easy enough to recover in post processing.
Used on a voigtlander 40mm for my Bessa R2, the warming does wonders
This is far and away my favorite filter. I love to add a slight warm hue to all my photography. Of course, the added lens protection is also a nice bonus.

This is a nice addition to any camera bag.  Took 2 photos of my wife without the lens, and then 2 with the lens.  Her skin tone with the filter is very nice and natural looking. I recommend this filter for any portrait shots, and maybe group shots.

Brings out wonderful colors.  Helped communicate what I saw when I visited Israel during a sunny trip.  Best investment I have made for my Olympus e510.  Protects lens and enhances photos.  Especially brings out great colors in portrait shots of my wife, who has somewhat "pasty" skin.  Makes photos look alive.
Makes skin tones look good. Use it if that's what you're after. Worth the buy for me. It stays on my lens permanently.

I ordered this Tiffen filter from Mountain Teacher September 4th and received it September 7th.  Thank you for the quick service Mountain Teacher.  The package arrived with the actual filter, in one piece, undamaged.  Tiffen filters are great and in this case seller service was exceptional.
Excellent. Only reason I give it 4 stars is because it was out of the package when I received it and was just laying next to the container in the box.
Necessary for intensifying morning and evening light when shooting landscapes or warming portraits.  It is one of the trinity filters; cpl; nd and warming filters

This lens turned a very mundane & flat looking sunset into a quite stunning one, warm & vibrant.
The lens was a perfect fit for my camera.
I can recommend this lens to anyone who wants to achieve good depth of color in sunsets  or add a warmer color to portraits.

The warming filter does a great job of punching up my otherwise cold scenes.  I suppose most of the effect could be done in digital post-processing, but I like seeing a warmer picture from the get-go.  Plus, this guy was super cheap when I got a promotional price on it for buying a lens.

Was pleased to see this filter arrived on time and had no packaging issues. This warming filter is not only great for portraits, but is also good for adding warmth to landscape scenes. Filter arrived with no scuffs or scratches, and with all Tiffen filters it attaches to the lens smoothly. I would highly recommend this filter!

I've always had great results from Tiffen filters.  This one however was a disappointment.  I don't know if it was a factory-second or if it was just a product that slipped through quality control inspections, but it was obviously defective upon initial inspection.  The glass lens was not seated in the metal ring correctly.  It was all catty-whampus.  This made it impossible to place another filter on top of it or to even attached the lens cap.  Over about 30% of the circumference of the filter, the lens/retaining ring sat less than one thread below the outer surface of the ring as if on installation it had been cross-threaded and was just cranked down until it wouldn't turn anymore instead of being removed and re-seated.  Not sure what I'll do now, maybe look at a Hoya.

it is an OK filter, in a budget and it does the job under cloudy skies or to improve some sunset photos, when not shutting in RAW.
However, it is not a high-end filter. I test it with prime lenses and it does decrease the quality of the image (noticeably), and it seems to be about one stop darker than expected.
The filter arrived promptly and in good shape.

I recommend it for domestic purposes.

When doing portraits of people with pale skin, they sometimes "wash out" into the background and you don't see many of the facial features; however, this filter does a great job of giving a little color to the person without it being noticeable that a filter was used. Great tool to have in your bag whenever shooting portraits.

Aerial photographs typically have an excessive blue tint and haze from dust and moisture. This filter is much more effective (than either a SKY 1-A or UVA Filter)  at cutting through the haze and warming the photo by reducing the excessive blue, especially on cloudy days. Also warms skin tones in portraits. Worth adding to your filter collection.

The effect from this filter is not very noticable. at all.. from the preview images and reviews I was expecting something along the lines of an Instagram filter, where things really change. But Alas, it is nothing like that and post processing will always be needed I suppose! the build quality is great though.

High quality filter.  Creates warmer (as per the name) look in many images.  My wife loves how it helps her pale skin tone look a little more brown and lifelike.  I leave it on my camera lens all the time.

A filter is one of those things that is very personal opinion.  Try it for yourself - if you like it, keep it.  If not, return it.  I like mine.  Some are cheap and use cheaper glass.  This one seems good.

I've used the Tiffen 812 Warming Filter for over 30 years. I have the 812 on all of my camera lenses. It not only has a nice warming effect, but it also absorbs UV light. Film and digital are both affected by UV light, making an image a little blue. Also it's a good idea to keep one on each of your lenses, to protect the front lens element. After using the 812 I would never go back to using an ordinary skylight filter again.

It warms up the color but I wouldn't use it solely for everything. I wouldn't recommend to use it in portrait. The filter pink-like color. So, it pop ups anything in range of this spectra, means: the red tone will be added to your face. A combination of 812 filter with UV Sigma filter reduces this effect and, actually, makes skin color look more natural, I'd compare that combination with Cokin 81C filter. The Tiffen 812 transparency is about half stop, what adds a bit contrast to your pictures. The filter (62mm) well made and did not give a vignetting at 18mm focal length (with Sigma 18-200mm lens) even with UV Sigma filter on. The filter has internal thread which allows to put on another 62mm filter.
All in all, the 812 warming filter enhances pictures, it did make my pictures soft, the price is right, in my opinion - worth to buy.

Using this with Ektachrome slide film and it really made a huge difference to control the bluish cast I get on that film and the slight magenta corrects any green cast I get. Subtle warmth and the proper filter to use when warming up an overcast day or to add some warmth to your scene in general.
Just used for one shoot however the color is a subtle warmth that I can see it help bring out a great skin tone for people it a natural setting. I can speak on this for a flash setting

it was missing the hand strap for the camera.  Other than that the case seems to be of good quality and my camera fits perfect in it.

I made some research about my last camera purchased, and really the best case that fit exactly and with great quality craft, seems to be MEGAGEAR LEATHER CASE. i purchased this case for my canon sx260 and it fits great. the quality of the leather wonderful. it's lined with black felt inside. the button closure is magnetic which is a nice touch. it comes with a black leather hand strap for your camera and a sholder strap. it does the job and looks great doing it. thanks for making a great product.

I bought a compact Lumix ZS15 camera for a reason.  I wanted one that would easily fit in my purse and be taken out at a moments notice.  I also needed a case to protect it that wasn't bulky and could be easily accessed as well.  The MegaGear leather case fits my needs perfectly!  It is both attractive and functional.
