The photos I have attached is from watching a movie on a 100” screen. Color is great even on live action shows. The bottom corners are never 100% in focus but I also have my projector mounted from the ceiling and it’s not bad, they are just barely out of focus in my Roku menus and movies never use the bottom corners so it hasn’t effected our viewing quality. We did have an issue with a sound bar. We had a pass through sound bar set up so our Roku went through the sound bar then the sound bar attached via hdmi to the projector and it worked great for an hour, then the picture started skipping and it started making a high pitched squealing noise. We hooked the Roku directly into the projector with no sound bar and it worked great again. We haven’t tested it up to the 300” but at 100” it’s like having a personal movie theater in our home.

2 year update: projector is still working fine. Movie nights with the kids are a blast!
Update: Yaber just reached out to me again. They are sending me a new Y31 and told me to keep the defective one. Although,  I'm frustrated and it's been over two weeks, it's good to know they are standing by their product. I'm satisfied for now.

Original review: Well, it was good while it lasted the 8 months. Now there is a horizontal line in the middle of the screen. Top part color is a bit darker than the bottom part. This happened suddenly. Nothing hit the projector as it is mounted high up. Yaber support tried to help me 3 times over the course of a week or so, but could not resolve the issue. Then, told me there is nothing else they can do, but contact Amazon. Their description says "YABER provides 6-month back and 5-year repair...", but don't believe it. Great picture while it was, but I'm going to have to recommend staying away from this one.

I got it in time for Halloween and it made everything great. The picture is bigger, sharper, and brighter than I hoped for at this price point. It’s super easy to set up and use right away. I don’t have a screen yet so I just threw up a sheet and it was great for now. Also I used it in three spots in one night: I pointed it towards the front bay window on rear projection for a Halloween scare for my son. I need to figure out a better screen for that situation so I wrote the company and the owner wrote back offering to help. That’s pretty incredible nowadays. Then we moved it outside and it was amazing on a sheet. Then we set it back up in the movie room. Super easy and light to move and set up. So, honestly, with the pandemic going on and no Halloween this year-this projector kind of was the hero that saved Halloween. Looking forward to using it like this for the upcoming holidays. I guess something like Bluetooth might be helpful but you can get a usb dongle for that if you need it, but my Amazon fire sends it to my speaker or my laptop does too. I’m in the film industry and did a lot of research before buying. For a non 4K true HD 1080 projector, I honestly don’t think you’re going to find a better deal.

I waited months to write this review so I could test the unit. I have to say this is a fantastic projector! Its bright enough to use durring the day (don't expect miracles but I can watch most things with the lights on illuminating the entire screen). The fan is a little loud but for how bright it is I appreciate the attention to thermals, hopefully giving this unit a long lifespan. The best feature is the digital keystone correction! So normally with a projector like this if your not dead level and the projector is not pointed at the dead center of the screen you will have to adjust the keystone manually to create a plumb image (perfect rectangle). The issue with that is when you adjust the mirror to correct the shape of screen a little focus is lost at the very top or bottom, this can be most observed in netflix looking at words. However with this beauty you can set the manual keystone to get not a plumb image but perfect focus on the entire screen, then use the digital keystone to get a perfect rectangle. The end result is a perfect or as close to perfect as you can get image.

Love this projector and hope for years of use out of it!

Overall this projector is great. there are two brightness settings, the brighter setting works pretty good in a room with closed blinds but still a lot of natural light. would definitely not work outside during daylight like I had hoped.
The main limitation I've run into is the size of the projection. the dials allow you to adjust the sharpness at a given distance, but the actual size of the projection is solely based on the projectors distance from the screen or wall. Basically you need to physically move the projector further or closer to the wall to change the screen size (some other projectors allow you to do this with a dial on the lens, this model does not).
Not a huge deal, but something to keep in mind.
Also works great for mario kart at night on a 20x40 canvas in the back yard! (a little fuzzy on the corners of the screen this large, but so much fun)

I have owned this for about a year. I bought it for a family reunion camping trip in the mountains. It is bright enough to start the movie just before it's totally dark. I love it, and we've used this almost every month during the summer months outside. The pictures are from a block party we had on June 24, 2023.
Video Player is loading.

I bought this projector mainly because of the 6800 Lumens if offered, and partly because of the resolution. I can tell you that the brightness is a lie. With that brightness you should be able to watch a movie in plain daylight, and it is not possible with this projector. I have a quite old 2600 Lumens projector, and you really can't tell much of a difference with it regarding brightness. And the picture, even when the resolution is high, you can't really focus it in order to read clearly very small numbers (like the movie's length or the current minute you're in). I think there is a problem with the corners or the sides, or maybe you need a really flat surface and for the projector to be perfectly aligned perpendicularly to it, to reach a better focus, that with my older projector I did get.

As for the onscreen menu, again, my old BenQ projector is much more complete and professional looking.

I should have guessed this was not a serious company when they have an outlook.com email address, and don't even have a website.

Maybe I'm asking too much for my money, since it is really not that expensive, but if you offer something you must deliver. You can't advertise what is not true. It is totally misleading. I am very dissapointed. I guess that for this price I couldn't honestly get anything better; however, I expected the information provided to be true. And I don't think that their customer service, for what I have seen, is even going to answer the email I sent, or that they even have any solution or alternative other than returning it (if that is even possible).

I bout this YABER Y31 over two years ago and the projecting light went out, I wrote them an email, they ask me for photos and details of the problem and the took care of me beyond my expectations, I got another projector in about 2 weeks. It is great to know that they are standing behind their product for 3 years … I would recommend them anytime.

I use this in my room, although I have used it on a 17ft projector screen. (27ft diagonal). I ended up losing my remote and upon contacting the company, they shipped me a new remote completely free! It’s been a few years now and i would say the only con I have found would be the slight noise increase over the years. I attribute it to dust in my room, so overall I would recommend this projector as it has a very large screen size (which is digitally adjustable) as well as a great picture quality.

This is my first projector and so far it is working great and I’m very pleased with it.  I’ve only used it with a fire stick but it works seamlessly with it. It’s not quite as bright/clear as my nml LED TV but the picture quality is great and much better than I had expected. The Picture quality definitely improves with less light but the projector is bright enough that it does not have to be extremely dark out.
The remote is very simple and intuitive. The only thing that will take a little getting used to is the Keystone adjustments to make the picture perfectly rectangular. There is an automatic adjustment option but I haven’t figured that one out yet.
I definitely like the fact that there is a fine focus ring right on the projector that is quick and easy to use rather than having to go into the menu to do it.
The option to decrease the screen size is also great and convienant and prevents you from having to reposition the projector if the picture is to big for the screen.
I am planning to only use it for front projection from a stand but it also has the option to use from the rear and can be hung from the ceiling as well.
The built in speakers aren’t going to wow anybody but are definitely more than adequate to keep my kids entertained while watching outdoor movies. That being said you do have the option to connect to an external speaker via audio cable.

With the reality of being stuck home during the pandemic, I had opted to create a home theater experience for my family. Before I would consider getting an expensive projector, I figure I'd get a cheap one to see how much I actually used it before saving and committing to a more expensive projector. The Yaber projector is a mixed bag. Here's Why:

Cons:
-Not suitable for daytime use: The furthest extent of light it can handle is lamps at night in the room not directly around it. Sunlight bleeds out the image drastically.
-Contrast Ratio has much to be desired: The range is pretty limited. Want white white, black with be gray, and what black blacks, image will be dark. I tried a variety of combinations when it came to the contrast/brightness settings and I could never find a sweet spot due to the projector's limitations
-The remote worked for a week, now I am unable to use it. Amazon said I had to send back the whole projector and they couldn't get hold of the manufacturer. Keep this in mind when buying it. It breaks, you own it.
-Fan Noise is Loud
-corners blurry

Pros:
-Although no mechanical zoom function, there is a digital image reduction for up to 75%
-At the price you get a pretty big screen projection for the money
-Image quality is good enough for watching movies (4K has spoiled us)

In summary, if you want a 1080p projector for under $500 to see if you like it, this is it. Just don't be surprised if the lack of quality rears its ugly head in time.

I have been waiting for 8 years for a projector like this one. I cannot believe the quality of this projector for this price point. It does not have a metal halide lamp as many do it but it uses a bright LED lamp. Again not something you find in a $250 unit. It also has a LCD screen through which the lamp projects and not a crazy wheel of colors that cuts down on the output. From my research it appears that the projectors that use a color wheel that spins in front of the lamp tends to cut the lamp output by 1/3 or more. That means a 6000 Lumen lamp is putting out 6000 lumen, but what gets outside the projector is only about 4,000 lumens.

I am not an expert by any means but I am in pressed after doing a bit of research on projectors. I was able to clearly see the projection even with lights on in the room. And this unit does work with Dolby Surround Sound which is why I went with this projector. The controls seem fairly straightforward and the remote is very simple. I did a little bit of playing with the vertical Keystone and it worked sweet.  I am anxious to get a ceiling mount and hook this projector into my system.

At this point, after reading several reviews, I was pleasantly surprised with what came.  And even at 12 feet from the screen, I could not get it small enough to fit on the screen!

Oh, i sent an email to the Yaber customer service and received a response in 2 hours.  Can someone be better than Amazon at customer service?

I have had a home theater since 1998 - at that time I had a Panasonic that cost me around $1,400. I  recently purchased something from Dr J and returned, it was awful. Then I read both 5 star reviews and 1 star reviews for the Y31 and decided to purchase it. In a word - Awesome.  I dont say this lightly,  I can be very critical in my evaluation but this projector exceeded my expectations.
I'd like to address some of the 1 Star complaints.
1 - some had issues with the headphone jack as the only audio out option. I was easily able to go from that output into some inexpensive powered speakers and the sound is great.
2 - some say if you get focus in the top you'll be out of focus on the bottom. This really puzzles me because as I set-up the unit and it was clear and completely in focus from top to bottom. I like to watch movies with closed captioning and the focus was remarkable.
Take time to play with the set-up so the amount of color,  brightness, etc suit your needs. This unit (Yaber Y31) will accommodate your specific needs. I do stand amazed at the value of this unit at this price - Home Theater Lives - just get some popcorn and raisinettes and your all set ( Die Hard included in photos).

I got the projector back on Christmas of 2020. Worked great used it a lot. Recently the display had a dark spot that appeared making it hard to see well. I decided to contact customer support about the warranty. It took a couple days to talking via email but everything was okay as they replaced the projector. They also gave tips on making it last longer as well.  So I would definitely recommend!!

Hello - I love this projector and it's had excellent quality picture and sound, but unfortunately am seeing yellow "burn-in" after a little over a year of use.  This version allows you to clean the lens, but that didn't help, so am assuming this burn-in is occurring on the chip and unfixable?
I just wish they could fix the burn-in problem, as it's a great projector otherwise.

Recently purchased. This is a great projector with both automatic and manual adjusting options for focus and keystone correction. The picture quality is clear and the internal speakers really create a loud and clear sound.

The input multiple options are also very helpful, especially the HDMI and USB ports. That way you can leave a more permanent setup and not have to continue changing cables from different sources. You can use the HDMI inputs for cable boxes, video game consoles, and Blu-ray players. You can use the USB ports for streaming sticks and stored videos. And you can use the VGA cable to hook up to a desktop or laptop, if you have a more office-functional idea for using the projector. The rear and front projection options are also great to have as they give you more options on where to set the projector and your screen.

You can also purchase an AnyCast USB adapter that will add a wifi streaming/mirroring option which is convenient if you don't want to deal with cables.

One wish is that it came with a traveling/packing case for portability. But that may seem a little unnecessary to certain users who are not planning on moving the projector place to place.

Overall great product, especially for the price. It is an extremely superior entry-level projector, and doesn't break your wallet if you're considering starting to use projectors for viewing experiences. I see myself enjoying more and more sports games and movies outside this summer.

The Yaber Y31, made by friendly people attuned to customer service, offers many big-time specifications and features for its moderate price. The menu is easy to understand and navigate, though the potentially useful option to reduce the screen size by 25 percent is not always easy to trigger with the arrows on the unit or the remote. The picture is bright and the 3-watt internal speakers produce adequate sound. There are plenty of inputs on the back, with two USB ports on one side. Be sure, however, that your indoor space is of the right dimensions to make the most of the Y31. When I placed the projector in my usual place for a projector, 15 feet from my living room wall, the enormous screen covered much more than my white wall, and lost much of the image by plunging deep into the bathroom. Even with a reduction, the screen remained too big. (Optimal throw is between about 5.8 and 12.8 feet, the very good user manual said.) It wasn't practical in my rustic summer cottage to move the projector forward for a smaller (and presumably sharper) image, nor was the sharpness at the long distance all that I wanted, so I reluctantly returned the product. There should be no problem at all outdoors. I like Yaber's design and engineering, and I will be a future customer.

I've tried setting this projector up a ton of different ways and the corners are always blurry. It's tough to read tv stations especially during sports games. The color isn't bad but when watching soccer or American football the green is well over saturated... And that's turning the green hue almost off. The keystone is near impossible to get correct as well. I really want to love this projector because the brightness is spot on for my basement and my backyard. Also it's light and easy to transport. I'm not gonna give up on this since I see all the other good reviews. Maybe it's something I'm doing wrong or maybe it's my machine.

I was initially very happy with my purchase. However, the bulb has been extremely dim since roughly that 1.5 year mark. I understand it's a lower end device, but the marketing sure set a much higher expectation. Save your money and buy a higher-end projector because you will have to upgrade sooner than you think anyway.

What I liked: 1) The picture quality was good. I used a light grey painted wall for the screen and colors were surprisingly good. The room, at the time, had lots of daylight so the picture wasn't as bright as an LED flat screen, & I expected that. 2) The sound quality was good also. It was crisp and clear. 3) The setup and adjustment was pretty straight forward. I had no trouble. My dislike was the fan noise. I set this up in a quiet room, a place where the volume for viewing would be low, and the sound of the fan was just too much for what I needed. The other thing that really rubbed me wrong was the statement from the manufacturer included in the box: "Due to Amazon's rules, once a customer makes a comment, our seller cannot find the buyer's contact information in any way, making it difficult to have a two-way conversation and quickly resolve the issue. The product gets a huge impact from your negative review, and you don't get your problem solved quickly."  This just strikes me as a threat to not give bad reviews or they won't help you resolve problems in a timely manner.  For this, and the fan sound issue I returned the Projector.

I bought this projector 3 yrs ago hoping it would be brighter than my bulb projector, it is a tad brighter. Over all it hasn’t been too bad of a projector for night time use but some dark shows are difficult to watch such as the Walking dead which has a lot of night time scenes. All the darks blend together and it’s really hard to make out what is going on. My chief complaint about this projector is the mid to top right corner of the screen is now turning orange. The projector may have 100 hrs of usage. I wouldn’t expect it to be fried already.
Video Player is loading.

My original projector was a named brand 720p that cost about $550, and lasted about 3 years. The picture was completely burned even after bulb replacement. That’s relevant because I’ll use that as a comparison to this projector.

For half the price I was reluctant, but am blown away by the picture quality and brightness. I use it on “low power” and it’s plenty bright, it’s pretty loud on “high power”.

It’s bigger than my name brand projector, but I suspect that’s because of standard size PC fans in either side, it seems to run much cooler than my name brand projector which is good because my name brand projector ultimately overheated.

The remote is super cheap and doesn’t have some of the cool features my name brand projector had.

The keystone works good, but not as good as the name brand. My set up is less than ideal due to throw distance and a ceiling fan, it’s at quite the angle, but I managed to get it pretty close.

The throw distance was the exact same as my old projector, and so was the power cord( has to splice the original to make it longer)  so it was literally plug and play for me with the
same mount I had been using.
Video Player is loading.

I will start by saying that the picture quality is excellent. It really is 1080p full HD. The brightness is also excellent. So the overall image this projector provides is definitely 5 stars.

However...there is NO ZOOM FEATURE. So buyer beware. I am an audio visual tech. I have installed and trouble shot, many many high end projectors. Clearly, this is not a high end projector, but it’s great for the price. Yaber will tell you that the zoom feature is in the “picture menu”. They will tell you that you go into that menu, and then into the submenu, entitled “image reduction”. Really?? No. All that image reduction does...is reduce the size of the image. In other words, zoom out. Any quality projector always has a zoom in/zoom out feature. That is a VERY basic feature. To not have that is very odd indeed.

So in short? You literally have to mount (if you ceiling mount this projector as I did) the projector either a bit too far away from the screen, then zoom in, (“image reduction) OR...mount it EXACTLY where it needs to be. Very inconvenient.

So be aware of this, before you buy this projector. It will save you a huge headache. Had Yaber included this little tidbit of information in the product description? It would have saved me A LOT of time and frustration in the installation process. Yeah. Not cool.

So 4 stars. I would’ve given this projector 5 stars...if it had a normal zoom in/zoom out feature.

Again, this is not some “luxury” feature. Every projector is supposed to have a basic zoom in/zoom out. It should be automatic.

All I can say is we love this projector!! Very pleased, would definitely purchase again. Was so surprised of the image quality for the price. I bought it to make a budget theater in my basement. After seeing so many positive reviews, for this, was so very thankful I did. As can see from my pictures, I put up a 150" screen, and it fills it very nice, bright to the edges, I'm sure it could go bigger no problem. The screen measures 6" high by 11" wide of viewable area, projector is 15' away, fits perfect under my 7' ceiling. We sit like 6' back, and get the immersive feeling I was looking for, like you would get in the theater! Projector gives lots of hookup options, even gives you some cables you need. Everything but popcorn! I connect to a sound system, but the built in speaker sounds great too.
Also used it last Halloween to project a video in our window, we had compliments from pretty much everyone! Just used a cheap frosted shower liner and long piece of molding, and hung in the window. A company with atmos in the name has all kinds of videos you can download, for just this purpose!
Super happy with and would recommend!

If you want a projector with a great picture for a very good price, then this is the projector for you.  If you want a projector with all the bells and whistles, this may not be the projector for you.  No Bluetooth, no WiFi, no CEC, no adjustable zoom.  Though, for a real big-screen experience, you will need external speakers.  The screen brightness is pretty good, but a darker room is still better for crispness and clarity.  The remote control is very similar to a FireTV remote with tactile buttons.  The internal speakers are rather quiet, but they do overpower the sound of the fan.  About audio output, there is a 3.5mm headphone jack, along with a 3.5mm A/V jack which could be used to get stereo sound.  If you want to connect a surround sound system with digital (coaxial or optical) input, you will need an HDMI splitter that has a digital audio output on it.  In short, there is no way to get true surround sound from this projector without additional equipment.  Again, this is no BenQ projector, but at the $225 that I scooped this projector up for it is well worth it.

I compared this with other projectors during daylight. The projectors were in the same price range as well as mini projectors - All rated with 4.3+ stars.

Compared Projectors:
1st Place: Yaber 6200 Lumens (B07Q2BV8LN) - Brightest, clearest picture quality, and fan was less noisy than the others.
2nd Place: Yaber 6000 Lumens (B07WS7XFLG) - Was nearly as bright, picture quality was about the same as the 6200, but the fan was about 30% noisier than the 6200.
3rd Place: Yaber 6500 Lumens (B07XKS5PQG) - Although it had more lumens, I'd say the brightness was equal to the 6200, the picture quality was good but not as good as the 6200 or 6000, and the fan was about 40% noisier than the 6200
4th Place: Vankyo Leisure 510 (B07GDNVND9) - Not as bright, picture not as clear
5th Place: Vankyo Mini Leisure 3 (B078KF8CSX) - Nowhere near as bright as the regular sized projectors, picture not clear, just upgrade to the bigger ones
6th Place: AuKing Mini (B07MTCMHZX) - Terrible, do not buy

Compared to TV:
Unfortunately, none of these were nearly as bright as my LED TV (Toshiba 4K Fire TV). I'd say the Yager 6200 is only about 30% as bright as my TV. So if you are looking for a complete TV replacement, this will disappoint in terms of brightness (at least during the day).

Further Observations:
All these 'budget' projectors are clearly made in China. There are other products that look exactly the same (search "6200 Lumen Projector"). Name branded projectors range in the thousands. So, in terms of 'bang for your buck', any projector that looks the same probably is the same, and is your best bet.

This could be 4 or 5 stars.  This is the first projector I have ever had so I am no expert.  I originally was given Yaber Y21 for Christmas. To my disappointment, it was defective and wouldn't work. However, the support people responded quickly to rectify the problem where I returned it and decided to get this model instead. On the projector itself, I have setup a 120" screen and it is fairly easy to setup. I have it hooked to my Roku device. The ability to shrink to screen is helpful, because it allows me to position it where I want to. For sound quality, I am currently use the Yaber device. I'm pretty impressed with how it sounds for a projector. It has good depth and doesn't seem to be coming from one speaker.  I only wish I could get it louder.  But since I can make my room look like a dark theater with a large screen, I'm thinking I'm going to invest in a good sound system to give a more theater effect.  But all in all I have a nice 120 inch screen, good clarity, good sound for under $300.  No way could I have afforded it with a normal TV.

I have a tech background and am very picky about the quality of the AV equipment I purchase. About a month ago, I purchased a smaller 720p native projector with 5000 “lux” because the price was well under $100. While that projector did work fine for a kids basement playroom (very dark), I found the image quality and brightness to be so poor that I would never choose to sit down and watch a show or movie on it without my kids.

I did quite a bit of comparative analysis and settled on the Yaber Y31 primarily because of the advertised 7200 “lux”, 10,000:1 contrast ratio, and LED light source while still maintaining a price under $300. For the price paid... the Y31 is excellent. No doubt better projectors can be purchased, but I felt investing in a more expensive projector also warranted investing in the rest of the high dollar equipment that goes along with it (screen, surround sound). Before you know it, you are into a fun idea for well over $2000.

I still prefer the vibrance an actual TV for daily/regular watching, but this projector is a great, inexpensive solution to achieve that theater effect. I am projecting around 130”-140” on a gray wall (PPG Storm’s Coming) and am using a Roku 4K streaming stick as a source. I also opted to use the Roku App “Private Listening” feature with a wired speaker for better sound without having wires strung all over my room. Tip: a big screen seems even bigger with big sound.

_____________________

Photo 1: Smaller, brighter screen is the Yaber Y31. The larger dimmer, screen is the Elephas E9. I know the Y31 is closer to the wall which may make it slightly brighter, but it was easier to take the photo and the Y31 maintains almost identical brightness at full size.

Photo 2: Mandalorian at 130”ish in an nearly blacked out room.

I really wanted to like this projector, and TBH, the same day (Sunday) delivery from Amazon did get me out of a Monday morning bind when the 12-year old conference room projector blew its lamp ballast power module (which is no longer available), BUT there are some major gaps in quality between them...

One may need to wear out a few sets of batteries in the remote before the color balance is acceptable, and some of that may be just giving up and settling for the bluish-green tint that doesn't seem to be correctable - whites just aren't!  It's conceivable that the color issues could be corrected by a software update, although I'm doubtful, but the biggest flaw that is absolutely NOT correctable, is that the optics are really cheap.  Focus the center of the screen, and only about 10% of the screen will be in focus, and the outer edges will be very blurry, so you will have to compromise on your focus.  Didn't have this issue with the last 2 projectors mounted in the exact same spot, so I know it isn't my screen.

In addition, the cheap optics means that there is NO manually (optical) adjustable throw - they handle that function by allowing you to digitally adjust the size of your picture to frame your screen if it doesn't fit exactly where you mount your projector.  A far cry from the previous model, and you can completely forget about color calibration. The remote doesn't come with batteries (2x AAA), but the unit cheap, and that's part of where they cut corners to shave the cost...

It probably isn't fair to compare this quality level to a projector quality that cost 3-4 times as much, but the glowing marketing will never warn folks about the shortcomings of this product, and I am not sure I would have bought it if I'd know beforehand what I would get.  In this case, you get a cheap projector, so if you're looking for a cheap 1080p projector, this will do you, and it's probably ok for watching a movie on, but a full-screen spreadsheet will give you a headache trying to focus on most of it, because it just isn't physically possible.  Watching sports on it might be ok too, but I don't know, as I don't.

This one will stand in for now, while I shop for a better replacement, and then it will sit on the shelf as an emergency backup only.  There's no reason for me to update this review down the road, because the major flaws with this unit are baked-in, and can't be fixed, so it can't really get better where it counts.

This little projector is very capable. I've been using this projector for the past 2 weeks in a brightly lit room. Like any other projector of this class, I can only use this after nightfall as even small amounts of natural sunlight greatly reduces contrast. However, incandescent lighting in neighboring rooms at night does not seem to have much impact. So you don't need total darkness.

In my case the projector projects clear images on a 100" screen. The projection distance is about 14-ft. I like the feature of having a zoom adjustment. This allows the image to be scaled down to 75% which I need for the distances and screen size. Images upto 120" are still pretty clear. The projection suffers during fast action sequences however.

While it is true that the projector takes Dolby AC-3 sources, the inbuilt speakers are not strong. The fan is not very quiet either and you need the projector at least 5-6 feet away from you for it to be less annoying. The projector only outputs analog stereo sound. So if you need to enjoy full surround you would need a capable HDMI splitter or route the video source through your receiver and connect its monitor output to the projector.

Having a manual keystone (to keep image perfectly rectangular) adjustment is also great. I try to keep my projector head-on and minimize the need for it. It works well for minor corrections. Larger corrections make images sharp on one side and less so on the other. I have not tried the remote control and have not found a need for it. I am able to achieve reasonably crisp focus with the manual focus ring as well.

Out of the box, the projector seems to have good color balance. The power cord is of reasonable length. The included HDMI and audio cables is a bonus.

I hightly recommend the projector for casual viewing. If you are a videophile, I suggest you look elsewhere.

Overall, the projector is pretty basic, but good & the horizontal keystone is a must have feature.

However, I do have an issue with the horizontal keystone. While it retains the settings (the value) after power dn/ up cycle, it is not reflected on the screen (meaning the angle is off). If i use the remote to change the value by one & then back to the setting that is saved it the applies the change to the screen.  Support asked if i make adjustments every time, but I don not.... it is a bug in the settings & the projector just will not retail the keystone angles I set once it is powered off.  It is really frustrating that I have to reset this every single time I turn on the projector.

Also, I was promised a free projector screen with purchase but I still never received it, even after a few emails to Yaber.

When reaching out to support, they appear helpful, but they don't really follow through on resolving any of the issues I have had.
Video Player is loading.

We were looking for a good projector to use for outdoor movies over the summer — projecting them onto a screen we hung about five feet into our garage and projected from out in the driveway  (Our garage is east-facing).  I found that we were able to start movies with reasonable visibility 20-30 minutes after sunset.  It was not bright enough to run it any earlier than that though in an outdoor setting.

Clarity was a challenge, though.  In order to maintain equal focal clarity across the entire span of the picture, you couldn't muck with the pitch or angle correction on the projector.  Doing so would invariably make one end more out of focus than the other and would throw off the clarity.  So if you don't mind the top and bottom of the picture being slightly distorted in size (if projecting from near the ground), you can get a relatively even focus level.  But the minute you start adjusting the angle of the picture, you will degrade the focal quality.

The onboard apps were nice for directly showing YouTube or Netflix videos — we used that on a few occasions.  MY BIG GRIPE THOUGH.... for services that require a PIN number (like Netflix) for parental controls, there IS NO MEANS to mask the PIN that you're entering.  "OK kids, everyone look away.... and no peeking!"  They really should address this and give a numeric pad on the remote control and mask the input of PIN numbers.

On the whole was good value for the cost, but lacked clarity and had minor user interface things that could have been improved.

Pros: 1.  Super clear and vibrant picture- way better than the other comparable projector I ordered to compare.  2.  Very bright- and I like the option on the remote to make it even brighter but didn't really need to in the pitch dark.  Haven't tried it outside yet but did with full light coming in the window in the early evening and with lights on (3rd picture) and still had vibrant colors and great quality.  3.  Adjustment to zoom or reduce screen size. Even though this has to be done with remote, it's a nice feature to have for different uses. 4. Easy set up and portable

Cons: 1.  biggest complaint (reason for only 4 stars)- No adjustment on the bottom to modify the hight of the lens when the unit is sitting on a table- this is odd as most others I have looked at had this adjustment.  This is an easy fix by just placing something under the unit to get it at the right height to project on my screen.  2.  No manual adjustment on the unit for zoom, has to be done with remote (more expensive name brand models have this but not a deal breaker for me).  3.  Speakers are not loud but I plan on using a sound bar so not concerned with that

All in all this is a great projector for the price range I was willing to pay.  Will just be using for family outdoor movies and other special occasions but really wanted a clear picture.  This is probably the best you can get without spending a lot more on name brand!
Pictures attached are on a 100" screen purchased from Amazon too.

We did a side by side comparison of the Yaber Y30 and Y31, the picture brightness is comparable to the extent that I couldn't tell the difference inside with the lights on but both were plenty bright in that scenario. The Y31 focusing mechanism is easier to work in general with less chance of your good hearted but clumsy friend getting their finger prints on the lens, a little harder to fine tune imo, but the "good enough" range is bigger. The user interface on the Y31 is more intuitive and more idiot proof, like anyone who's held a remote in the last 10 years could operate it without the manual. The Y31 remote does have one button that doesn't seem to do anything but to be fair I haven't looked in to it further. The Y31 has less options in some regards but overall better presets. The upward tilt on both is pretty primitive imo, with screw in front feet that you have to manually adjust, like screw them to x depth, put it down, how high is it, pick it up, screw them a little more check again, etc, but the Y30 only has 1 foot and the Y31 has 2 and feels more sturdy. The fan on the Y31 is considerably louder, and you can hear a big change when you switch from 6800 to 7000 lumens but, and this was the biggest deciding factor, the sound on the Y31, without exporting to external speakers, is so much louder and also more rich and varied. Just way way better. The Y30 has a standard/mono and two different surround sound settings and was alright, and presets for movie/music/sports/game, but can only export to left/right. The Y31 has all that but the internal surround sound option is loud enough at 50% that you can't hear the fan at all and any louder than like 60% would be too loud for our backyard on a school night, I could hear little tones/details in the couple familiar samples we listened to that honestly I never even noticed before, and you can adjust individually every tonal range/hrtz, as well as being able to be ingegrated with Dolby surround. So for streaming concerts or your fav tunes to muted cartoons, which is how I will most use my projector, I think there's really no question that the Y31 is the way to go.

Reading through the reviews and I’ll say folks should be realistic and understand you simply aren’t going to get a super high quality electronic device in something like a projector for $200. You just aren’t. If you’re looking for super high def, ultra clear, etc etc then spend the money on what you’re looking for and stop whining when you don’t get it at this price point. I’ve had this projector for nearly a year and aside from really slow customer service that is available only by email with zero other connect options it’s not a bad a little setup. Sound quality is terrible on its own but I added in surround sound and no more sound issues. Not very good in a room with a lot of daylight, it just isn’t bright enough, but for my bedroom that I’m only in at night the brightness is more than fine. As a primary device for a main room that I would use to watch tv on every day for everything this wouldn’t work and would not be a good option for that. As a secondary device for a darker room that you aren’t going to use for everything daily then you’re good. Again, be realistic in your expectations of a $200 projector and you’ll be fine. If anything, try it and if it doesn’t work for you then return it. You’ll figure it out in less than a week if it’s what you’re looking for.

We bought this projector over a year and a half ago, it has performed quite well and overall it has worked very well overall. We did experience an issue with the picture after having it for the time and we contacted the company and they followed through to address and resolve the matter. Support when buying a projector product is important as well as the term of the warranty. Yes, we would recommend this product.

First off, this is advertised as both 7,000 Lux and 7,000 Lumens. It's in no way a 7,000 lumen projector, it's somewhere around 1,000. But I knew for the price it couldn't possibly be that bright so it's OK.

To get the most out of it I made my own screen. Basically I painted a mixture of a quart of untinted metallic silver paint and 10oz of Seal Grey on a 4x8 sheet of MDF and made a PVC support/frame for the back of it. If you Google "Easy Ambient Light Rejecting Screen Paint" it should pull up a forum post from avsforum that goes into more detail. On top of that I also blacked out the windows to try to make the room as dark as possible.

You can get a surprisingly sharp image from this projector too but you really need to have it lined up just right. Usually, a projector is placed at the bottom of an image but this one seems to work best when leveled with the center of the screen, at least from a front projection, it may perform differently if mounted upside down. There's a bunch of keystone options to make the image fit however you have it aimed, but when you do that you lose image quality and the image may not be perfectly focused all around. It's worth it to spend the extra few bucks on a 30" or 40" projector stand depending on where you're projecting from and what to.

The very slight issue that I have is with the remote. It won't let me play files from a USB when I hit the OK button, but if I hit the OK button on the projector itself they play just fine. I've reached out to the seller and they are sending me a replacement remote. But even if that doesn't fix it, I'm OK with it because the projector will always be where I can reach it.

The speaker on it is pretty good for what it is but I usually connect to a soundbar. When the weather cools down and we do movie nights outside I'll just hook up to a small portable speaker I think.

Overall we've been very happy and have been loving our family movie nights!

UPDATE: I found that the remote works just fine. After selecting the video file on the USB you'll see a red check mark, then press the center top button for it to play.

I’ve never owned a projector before so I have nothing to compare this to. I wanted a decent projector to use for outdoor movie nights. I did a lot of research and this projector had the best features for the best price. I wish it had Bluetooth, but I realized I could pair Bluetooth speakers with the fire stick I’m using with the projector. So problem solved.

The biggest issue I’m having is adjusting the picture. I can’t get this to adjust right no matter what I do. The picture is always skewed wrong. I just ordered a projector tripod that I’m hoping will help with minute adjustments that I can’t get with just a table. The directions are pretty vague and I don’t fully understand how to get the picture to adjust fully. The last thing I want to do during a get together is spend the entire time trying to get the picture straight on the screen. I wish it had some kind of auto adjust feature. It’s clearly meant to be a permanently installed, adjust once, in home unit. I’m not sure if this is going to work for a quick outdoor, plug and play, movie night. I’ll keep working on the settings and see if I can get it to a point of not having to mess with it so muchevery time. It’s quite large, so know that’s it’s not anywhere close to a pocket projector.

The picture quality seems great though. I’m happy with the projection clarity and contrast. The brightness adjustment is a bit of a joke. It seems it only has two brightness options, light or dark. There’s no in between options that I can find. For the price it’s fine. I’ll take the word of the more experienced reviewers and the specs since I don’t have anything to compare it to.

The speaker is not great, so plan on hooking up other speakers. I’m waiting for the outdoor Bluetooth speakers I want to go on sale that I will pair with my Amazon fire stick. I did a trial run with my Echo and it paired perfectly.
Video Player is loading.

So I basically bought this projector because it was a very cheap alternative to replacing my trusty steed, an Optimum DPL 25 that is on its last legs. Can’t say I have been disappointed by brightness. The fan is a bit loud. The remote is great, but the most glaring off attribute about this projector is quite easily the color profile. I don’t know if this is normal, and maybe I’ll see some replies from either the manufacturer or other users, but the color profile runs insanely cool. A lot of blue and a lot of green. This was driving me nuts for a while, but despite that the picture has seemed pretty good. However, I think I may have gotten about as close as I can to a normal pallet but the settings are pretty extreme. While the user settings start red, green, and blue at 50 I found that I had to turn Green and Blue drastically down: Green to 14, and Blue to an incredible 08, while Red on the other end I have running at a whopping 98.

The biggest thing you’ll notice here is that this is an RGB projector. I still can’t complain because this is less than half the price of a better projector with a dimmer bulb. I don’t think this projector would be able to do so well with the brightness with the finicky nature of the YMCB color wheel.

Play with your settings, especially try to mirror something between two screens. If you’re using an Apple TV, I’ve noticed the ‘’ match frame rate” setting in the Apple TV definitely gets you better quality on playback. It also adjusts rather quickly, which it didn’t on my old projector, but at the same time I didn’t need to do that. Wish I had done a little more research before buying this since I watch a ton of movies and probably would have opted for something more expensive and accurate, but I have to say this is a game changer for daytime viewing. Overall, at this price point it’s pretty difficult to complain.

I got this Yaber Y31 for ~170.  Compared with Groview JQ818c (~140) and Nexigo PJ40 (~250 with coupon).

Groview JC818c did not have horizontal keystone, only vertical, but otherwise was quieter than Yaber Y31 and as good as or better picture, so if you don't plan to have it offset and need only vertical keystone, and want the best price, that one is a winner.

Nexigo PJ40 was nearly 100 more than the Yaber Y31, but the incremental picture quality, placement flexibility, and quietness were worth every penny.  That has 4-point keystone (Yaber only "4D" keystone which means only vert and horiz) so the PJ40 you can put high/low/to the side pretty much anywhere in reason and adjust to a good screen shape.  The Yaber Y31 was better than the Groview in placement but still restricted in comparison with the PJ40, along with being dimmer and noticeably louder.  The PJ40 fan is adjustable 1-10 with corresponding noise reduction - at 1 it's still plenty bright for most uses and is almost silent.

If you want to save the most money and you will always have your projector centered, Groview JQ818C has a good picture and is fairly quiet.

If you can spend 250, the Nexigo PJ40 you can put just about anywhere, great brightness and great quietness control.  Also its remote has HDMI CEC so you can control a connected Fire TV interface without changing remotes - fantastic.  A great deal in my opinion for what you're getting.

This Yaber Y31 falls in the middle price wise but doesn't really move the needle over the Groview.  It's okay if you absolutely need just vert and horizontal keystone and can only spend 170.

I bought a Yaber 31 and it was total junk.  Turns out it was simply a defective projector.  Yaber customer service was fantastic and made a few offers to help but after a couple of e-mails which they responded to the next day, they agreed to accept the return and gave us full credit.  In a previous review I gave the projector a 1 and customer service 5.  Yaber customer service then contacted me after issuing the credit and offered me a free projector.  Fearing a scam I told them they already gave me credit for the old one.  They again contacted me and ended up sending me another Taber 31 to try out.  My original projector was simply defective.  The new Yaber 31 works wonderfully in a smaller room, the darker the better.  One of my complaints was on the brightness. I thought this was a 7K lumens projector and it is 7K Luc.  There is a HUGE difference between a lumen and a lux after 1square meter. So if you room is more than 3X3 get ready for a dimmer picture. I tried the new projector in 3 different rooms. The first the size of a bedroom about 10x12.  Fairly dark great picture and the sound really surprised me at how good it was.  Turn on even one light and be prepared for a washed out picture.  Tried again in a 15X 25 room in low light and again good picture in the dark on the 15 foot wall.  Tried it in a 50X50 room with about a 17 foot throw up high on the wall.  That's where this projector really shines.  Not the large room terribly - washed out - but in the keystone correction.  Incredible how well it did and all controls are very easily run from the remote control.
Is this a good projector?  Depends on what you want it for.  I wanted it for the large semi lit room.  Not the projector you want for that.  Living room size or smaller?  The darker the better but a really good projector especially at the price point.  Especially if the LED bulb lasts as long as they say it will.  We spent almost as much on bulbs for the projector that this replaced as we did for the projector!  While the projector is pretty good making it worth a 3 star review, the incredible customer service and lengths Yaber went to, to make up for a bad projector and customer experience is overwhelming and bumps it up a star.  I would not be afraid to use this company again.  Fantastic experience in making sure the customer was satisfied.

----- Updated Sept 2022 -----
Yaber contacted me and offered to send me the latest version of this projector, Model V6. I'm updating the review to talk about the improvements in the V6 version. Note: I'm not sure which Amazon link is for V6, so you should
It's a lot noisier than I would have liked.

You get what you pay for with this projector. At the price, it’s a good option. You are not getting what you would get for a lot more, but I’m very satisfied with the picture quality and ease of use. I wish it had hdmi arc/earc, but it doesn’t claim to have that so I can’t complain about that. My only real complaint is fan noise, but you get use to it and my speakers drown it out.

For the price, I recommend it.

6/9/21 Update: Added 1 star. Ok. I decided to hook my Vivitek back up with a new bulb in it.  Picture is much clearer and easier to focus from top to bottom. The Y31 still looked terrible compared to my H1080 (ceiling mounted at 16ft) when using my long-run HDMI cord hooked to XBox.
I then hooked just a blu-ray player up to the Y31 and tried from 6ft 8in with no incline and the picture was a ton better. Then I moved it to 16ft with no incline (so stacked on some stuff to have 0-degree incline each time). The picture was still better than when connected to the Xbox, but not as crisp as when at 6ft 8in. I can't easily test the Xbox at the 6ft 8in distance, so not sure if it's the XBox, but I'm guessing it's the long-run HDMI (30ft maybe?) that was causing the really bad picture...although I have no issues with my Vivitek on this HDMI cable.
I will say that word or subtitles are still harder to focus on the Y31 regardless. It's really hard to get the top and the bottom clearly focused.  If you are watching normal shows or things without text...the blurriness is harder to notice and you could come to believe it's a 'crystal clear' picture. If this had been my first projector I'd probably have thought it was awesome. However, my Vivitek that is 10 years old looks way better, so I can't go back.
My takeaways: Y31..shorter your distance from screen...the better it will look. Brightness was good. Colors good in general. Contrast ok. I have a HD picture tuning Blu-Ray (Y31 was better on color than my Vivitek, but brightness and contrast adjusting not quite as good). It's good for a entry level and will get the job done, but I'm not sure how anyone can say it looks better than their 4k LCD tv. I will be returning. Not planning on any more tests, but if I do I will update.

Original: My Vivitek H1080 I purchased 10 years ago is much crisper and better looking. Colors more vibrant, text focuses easily.  I've been straining my eyes today trying to fix this to look better. I must say I don't believe this is native 1080p.  My Xbox One allows you to choose between 720p and 1080p output.  I've tried this and they both look essentially the same on a 120" screen. I can't see any noticeable difference.  I just got a bulb for my Vivitek as well, but was trying to avoid the $50-75 bulbs every year if an LCD would last much longer and give me the same quality.
Watching Netflix and such...seems like I went back in time as the picture isn't as good as anything I've had for a long, long time. I'm already leaning on returning this.  I like the price point of course and figured 10 years after my Vivitek this should be comparable at least.
I'm going to keep trying things for a bit, but unless there is a firmware update to fix this...I don't see much hope as
I've exhausted about all attempts to adjust.

I’ve purchased a few projectors over the last couple of years and used them for presentations, backyard movie nights, and the like, but they’ve all been ones that are HD SUPPORTED, not fully native 1080p projectors. I noticed a difference in the size of the YABER 31 right out of the box; it almost twice as large as the other two I own, and the lens is much larger as well (see pic). It was much easier to control the focus (it didn’t lock like my other two) and the picture quality was definitely HD. Even my wife, who can’t really tell the difference between DVD and BLU-Ray quality immediately notices how sharp and colorful it was when connected to our Apple TV (the pics are my projecting the image onto the side of our vaulted ceilings during the early afternoon; I’m sure it’ll be even better when we use it at night. You will want to do some image calibration out of the box to get the best image you can, but that’s a given with any TV or projector, and the settings are pretty straightforward.  The remote ACTUALLY WORKS and you have several types of inputs, from 2 USB ports, 2 HDMI ports, a VGA connector,  A/V input, all the cables you need for the connections, and outputs for headphones or external speakers. Speaking of sound (no pun intended), this projector comes with a better built-in speaker than my other two; I had them connected to an external speaker for sound and the sound quality on this one is noticeably better without connecting to an external speaker. The max screen size is pretty generous, more than enough for my 140” projector screen for outdoor movie nights. I’d say it was well worth the price point.

Before settling on the Yaber Y31 model, I had compared four other projector's, (including the Yaber Y30) from about 50 bucks up to this unit which was a little over $240 on a lightning sale. I decided seeing the difference between each one that it was worth the money in terms of long-term satisfaction of having a nice sharp clear picture with a native1080P resolution and the highest possible brightness and contrast ratio. Of course you can spend several thousand and have performance very close to a flat screen television but for much less I am very satisfied with the way this projector performs. It was especially nice to have on a camping trip as you see in the photos. We were amazed at the realistic look of Sandra Bullock and George Clooney floating around in space on a 10 ft. screen in the movie "Gravity" out in the beautiful wilderness of Colorado. Since it was pretty chilly at night, we pulled the car behind the projector sitting on a tripod mountable shelf, connected a bluetooth transmitter dongle to the audio output, and had a bluetooth speaker in the SUV, so we had our homemade drive-in theater while staying cozy warm in the car!

We used a 300W/500 WH battery invertor generator for power, and I had tested the time it would last and got about 3.5 hours out of it before having to recharge (using a solar panel the next day). So having the numbers from watt-hours and 3.5 hrs. run time, I figured the run wattage on the Yaber to be about 120-125 watts. I have seen the question raised repeatedly on various projector listing pages asking for wattage, pobably for this very reason- how long will my projector last on a battery generator? So it would be very helpful for more of these companies to give that statistic on the sale page (and the owner's manual) to help when calculating a model that fits needs for remote power, such as camping. I will contact Yaber and offer that suggestion to add that info.

I did dock the remote control by 1 star because Yaber went backwards from the Y30 to the Y31. The 30's remote had dedicated buttons for ff, rw, next, and go back functions, but on the 31 remote those functions require navigating an on-screen menu bar and hitting "OK". Why make the latest model less user friendly from it's predecessor?...so IMO, a backwards move...oh well...at least it's somewhat minor, and I love everything else about it, and would recomend it to others, keeping in mind that if you're picky about pictue quality, it's worth the higher price over the low level models, and Prime store card holders can easily afford this better model buing it with 6 months no interest payments, so it's a WIN-WIN!!

Had the yellow-brown spot start showing (as seen in several other reviewers photos) and they told me to send back the unit (at my expanse) and they’d send me a new one. It was only 5 mos old. I spent $30 to send it back and the communication completely stopped. So now they have my $230 projector that I spent $30 to send them and since they stopped talking to me, I just bought the Rovomko and like it so far. Brighter than the Yaber and it was nearly $100 less. Pass on this one!

SO HERE'S A NEW UPDATE...
This is crazy... So, I bought one of these in 2022, had the screen develop the brown spot, saw in reviews that they'd replaced faulty units, so contacted them to the point of  sending the unit back as you see above. Everything above was posted as my review after they failed to reply to me for a couple of months. Suddenly, though, they were able to reply to one of my email and had some story about how they had no communication ability for some reason, whatever. BUT, haha... they give me a whatsapp number to use to text them. Well, now I'm just interested... I installed whatsapp and contacted them and they tell me that if they send me a new unit, if it works great, would I remove my review? Sure, whatever. So the new one arrives, I take the Rovomko down, put this one up, and it's ok. Not as sharp as the original one I bought... actually, I should say, with the same settings, the keystoning seemed to adversely effect the picture - differently from my first one - and it was only very sharp in the center to top half of the screen. The first unit was pretty tack-sharp for 90% of the center of the viewing area. Again... whatever. Well, a couple of months go by and we are obnoxiously careful with the thing. If we watched a movie or show, we set the shutdown timer for 2 or 3 hours so there'd never be any question of overuse/leaving it on too long. Seemed ok for a couple of months, but then started developing the big brown spot - kinda looks like a  tornado in the center top right of screen, at least this time it's not dead center so actor's faces aren't discolored.
Now, today I reviewed another item and thought about editing my original review (the one that inspired them to contact me) and it was no where to be found, and the product is no longer available. So I click on "Write a Review" and it bring me to this screen, with everything up to today's edit populating the fields. So, that's a little "What the hell"-ish..

SO.. the crappy second unit is still playing... the spot seems to have stopped getting bigger, but certainly prominant... otherwise we've seriously just not dealt with it much... I end up just leaving my 8 year old HP Omen 32" on all the time and watching on that. But, eventually, I'll have a few minutes to put the Rovomko up there, and maybe there'll be a glowing review for them in the future. We still want to do the projector thing, but we're saving for an Epson or Sony. This one, no matter what, it seems, always ends up being a $250 paperweight.

And BOO on the company and how all this played out. Whatsapp, haha.

Because of the Stay at Home situation, family was coming from New York City to my rural area in order to escape COVID virus exposure. We kept thinking of things we could do since we couldn't go anywhere. At some point I decided to look into a projector so we could watch movies outdoors in the summer nights. I was an absolute novice as to what I was looking for in the way of a projector. I was teased at first because I had seen numerous projectors under $100 so that more than fit my budget without a doubt. Being the skeptic that I am, I stepped back and thought that it sounds too good to be true. I decided I need to become familiar with projector specs and scoured the internet further. I then came across some name brand projectors, like Epson, which were priced much higher in the $700 - $1,000 range - NOT in my budget. I did however look at the specs to see what it provided that cheaper projectors didn't have. I watched various YouTube videos to get more familiar and reached a point where I knew what to be careful about in the descriptions of less expensive ones. This made me realize that there are various deceiving claims to be aware of. Being confused with sooooo many projectors having brand names that were completely unknown to me, I was thinking maybe I should play it safe and buy from a local store so I could return it if I was not satisfied. I noticed that they favored just one brand with decent reviews and was priced around $300. However, before pulling the trigger, I searched the internet some more and focused on reviews. Lo & behold I came across the Yaber 31 projector which was in my price range, had great specs and the reviews were very favorable and so helpful. It was then that I felt very good about making a blind purchase of a brand I was not familiar with. I pulled the trigger to make the purchase. I was very pleased with the prompt shipping of my order. The package arrived earlier than the estimated arrival date. It came on a Friday together with the 100" folding screen I ordered from another merchant on Amazon. A few of us unboxed it that evening in eagerness to do our first outdoor movie night. We found a tree branch - hung the screen and began making adjustments. I had an Amazon Fire Stick I also ordered, so we plugged it in and it was pretty much an easy setup for our tech savviness level. We had a movie up and running within a half hour. As we fine tuned the projector to expand the full length of the screen, I became ecstatic how awesome the clarity and HD quality was being projected. Everyone was amazed and could not believe how nice our movie looked on a screen in the dark night of our yard. The projector itself has a very good sound, but we ran a Bose speaker via bluetooth then corded which gave us a better sound for everyone to hear. We had a successful showing with a group of 21 people and EVERYONE gave two thumbs up when the movie ended. Since that night, everyone has looked forward to our Friday movie night. Our crowd spread to neighbors coming over as well and said they've never seen anyone having a simple projector to view outdoor movies. They too commented positively on the quality and asked me where I purchased it. One night during the week, we projected YouTube video on an interior wall just before it was dark and actually had a viewable image. In the evening the picture became deeper in rich color and was just as amazing as the one on the screen. This Yaber 31 projector has been truly my best purchase of the year. Stop looking any further, add to your Cart and Checkout immediately before these might run out of stock and you'll miss the joy I'm having with it. Happy watching!

***** Updated 11Sep2021 ****
Yaber did contact me and agreed to ship a replacement projector. They paid shipping to me, but I had to pay the shipping of the faulty projector to them.
They said that the orange faded area is caused by using too much without giving it time turned off. I do use it regularly, but their description of the projector does NOT say that it is for intermittent use only. I asked if the failed part is something that  I could replace myself but did not receive an answer to that. Their response was "you should buy a more expensive projector". So all in all, if you are looking for a projector for intermittent use with very clear picture, good brightness, and less expensive, I suggest the Y31 from Yaber. The company was good to send a replacement. I don't know how many times to expect them to replace it during the 3year warranty. Time will tell. I'll update as time goes forward.

*****  Updated 17Aug2021 ****
This projector has been great for several months, but it now has a large section of the top right of the screen with an orange hue. [I saw another review saying that is caused by the polarizer.] I don't know what the problem is, but this unit stated that it had a three year warranty when I purchased it. Unfortunately, I cannot find a way to contact the company Yaber (their Amazon page does NOT have a contact section.)  I NEED HELP! This projector is not even one year old. I LOVED the picture when the orange areas was not there. But it is now very difficult to read portions of the screen where the orange section is located. PLEASE contact me to get this resolved. I will update the review appropriately afterward. Thanks.

 ----  Original Review ----
The picture is absolutely stunning! And after having owned an LED projector for several years, I was totally blown away by the level of brightness and contrast. Contrast is critical when watching videos that are darker themed. The brightness does not compare with the other brand projector with the 250W halogen bulb, but the price is also less than half. I can use this projector in a lighted room as long as the sun is not shining brightly thru the windows. In that case, we just close the curtains and continue :)  The digital keystone correction works very nicely as well, although the manual keystone correction is useless since the lens has a single focal length and slanting the lens causes either top or bottom to go out of focus. That's consistent on ALL manual keystone adjustment projectors. The happy thing is that this projector also has the 4D digital keystone projection that works flawlessly. I LOVE this projector.
For this price, you can NOT beat this purchase. MUCH cheaper than a big screen tv, and the picture quality is stunning! Get one!!!!

Honestly, I was not expecting much when I ordered this for $229. I was originally expected to receive this on the 8th of July, but somehow they shipped it out pretty much immediately and I received this yesterday.

Setup is extremely easy. Plug and play and everything is intuitive. No bells and whistles. Just plug in the wires, point at a wall (I am lucky in that I have a plain white wall in my bedroom so I didn't need a screen).

The picture quality genuinely surprised me in a good way. I was half expecting some sort of flaw, but for the price I got much more than I expected in terms of picture quality. This projector really is not meant to be used with ambient lighting which I didn't plan on doing anyways, so it suits my needs. I have black out curtains in my bedroom and I don't really like a lot of light, so this works for me.

It's definitely not the brightest projector in the world, but in complete darkness the contrast is fantastic. The color reproduction is great and the image is sharp where it matters. There are some out of focus areas at the corners, but when watching a movie that does not matter.

I set it up to about 90" without a screen and the image is still very sharp. It's definitely 1080p (in case anyone thinks that it might not be). I played 1080p video and 720p video of the same content, and there is a visible difference.

If you're a projector veteran, this might seem like it has a lot less features. But for my use it's more than enough. All I need it for is to watch blockbusters. I won't be using it for gaming. I tested it for gaming, and it's alright. If you're a PS3 era gamer (PS4 pro won't work on this as well because PS4 pro offers 60fps gaming, while this projector will only refresh at 24-30Hz as it's built for movies), I think this should be ok for you. I'm a PC gamer and this was definitely not up to the mark. I have a 21:9 34" 144Hz screen for gaming, so I don't need this.

You do need a stand. I have an adjustable laptop stand (with rise and tilt ability) which I am using and I would recommend getting something similar otherwise you won't have the best experience.

You also want to get a proper lens cleaning kit and clean the lens before first use because mine came with a lot of dust on the lens. It's not a big deal, but in case you have a dirty lens, you might end up with a blurry image and it won't even be the fault of the projector itself.

Overall:

Picture Quality: 5 out 5 (based on budget pricing)
Contrast Ratio: 3 out 5 (is not very effective during daylight or with any light really)
Color Reproduction: 5 out of 5
Features: 3 out of 5
Ease of Use: 5 out of 5

Recommended if you can pick it up for 230 again (seems like the 50 dollar off coupon wasn't being offered at the time of submitting this review). It might not be a bad investment at 280 even if you're looking for something that doesn't break the bank, but still gives a decent picture quality.

This is my first projector so I can’t compare this one to any others. I bought it for a new setup in my room, which will be in a couple of months. Right now I have it set up temporarily and projecting it to a textured (painted), off-white wall.

So far this projector has been awesome, even with my temporary set up. The built-in speaker is not bad at all. It does get a little tinny/buzzy at high volumes or with certain pitches, but it’s definitely sufficient for casual viewing. I plan on using it with a sound bar and an aux cable, which I have already tested. I also tested HDMI passthrough with another sound bar, and both work well.

The video quality is great, especially for a projector at this price point. Again, this is my first projector, so I don’t have anything to reference or compare it to. I don’t expect to be watching anything in super high quality, but it’s good enough for my bedroom setup. I’m using it with an Apple TV and a PS4 Pro. It’s very hard to see dark scenes even with just a little bit of ambient light, so it’s best to watch those in a very dark room. If you’re watching a show or playing a video game with a lot of bright scenes or environments, then it should be totally fine in a room with ambient light.

Set up is super easy and the menus are very clear and concise. It does have two levels of brightness, but they aren’t too drastically different. The brighter option does cause the fan to run louder. Speaking of which, the fan noise isn’t too bad. It’s definitely noticeable, but I personally tune it out after a minute or two of whatever I’m watching. Keystone adjustment is great and allows you to get a clear picture in all areas of the screen. The only thing it doesn’t have is zoom – or at least I haven’t figured out how to do it – so the screen size depends on how far away from the wall the projector is. There may be something about that in the manual, but I haven’t read it. Who reads manuals??? :)

Overall I’m very happy and excited about this and can’t wait to get a screen set up a sound bar hooked up to it. I’ll update my review if anything changes!

product_title: Fotodiox Pro Thumb Grip for Mirrorless Digital Cameras Black fits Canon PowerShot G12 G15 G1 x EOS M
product_description: Gives a better more secure grip for less effort Conveniently places thumb near the control wheel Made of high quality metal 24 Month Fotodiox Warranty

reviews.review_body: Perfect fit!!!
Makes the camera feel better in the hand; however, it blocks the on/off button slightly. It's made of metal and fits snugly in the hot shoe.
Fits on my eos-m like a charm, with no allen screw to have to turn. Really useful to have, and will keep it for other cameras.

Comparing two thumb grips for the X-Pro1.

Thumbs Up Grip TU-100B:
-Short (extends to the middle of the shutter speed dial)
-Adjustment screw

Fotodiox Pro Thumb Grip:
-Longer (extends to the middle of the exposure compensation dial)
-No adjustment screw

I bought both and the Fotodiox was much too tight. I had to use a hammer and punch to get it off and would have to file it down to make it fit. Since there's no adjustment it would need a very close fit for every copy (wouldn't mount at all on an EOS-M). The TU-100B looks like it's made to be loose and requires adjustment to fit but it's a safer bet. If you don't need it to be that long you might look at the TU-100B instead. I mainly wanted better grip for holding the camera in between shots but I don't find the shorter grip to be awkward for taking shots either. Either way, it's better than not having one since it does give a more stable hold and they won't cost you almost $200 for the one Fuji is selling.
Too big/thick will not fit into hot shoe for Canon Rebel 7 camera
Really improves the grip on my G12. Much less likely to drop it

However, my copy required slight adjustment by filing.  Another reviewer has dismissed this as unmountable.  Correct.  But just narrow the central upper "spine".  Judge the degree by upturning the grip, measuring against the fork of the hotshoe, and working on both sides with a fine file evenly until it  passes into the fork.  Then you will have super bit of support, especially for a larger hand.
